PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the committee's report entitled A report on a visit to Thailand and Laos.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the delegation's visit to Thailand and Laos in November and December 1994 has been tabled in advance of the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade's reference on Australia's relations with Thailand for two major reasons. Firstly, the delegation members were greatly impressed with what they saw in Thailand. They believed their views should be tabled as quickly as possible, without waiting for the overall report on Australia's relations with Thailand. Secondly, and possibly more importantly, the delegation took the view that, if it did not report on its short visit to Laos, matters it thought were important would be overlooked.

PARA.TAB: The foreign affairs subcommittee has been engaged on an inquiry into Australia's relations with Thailand since January 1994. To November 1994 we had held eight public hearings in Sydney and Melbourne as well as Canberra, taking evidence from a variety of individuals, private organisations and government departments. The subcommittee will hold its last hearing in Canberra next Monday, and the report on the reference will be tabled before the end of the year.

Thus delegation members were aware in general terms of the amount of reform and economic growth in Thailand over the past few years. We were not, however, prepared for the pace and variety of business and commerce in Thailand, or for the strength of that nation's intention to play a major role in the subregion. As the itinerary in appendix A to the report makes clear, while ours was not a long visit we were able to travel quite widely within Thailand. This does not mean we saw everything there is to see, nor that we are experts on that country. My colleagues will deal with particular aspects of the visit, but it is appropriate for me to pick out a few of the highlights.

The deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), will deal with the visits to Hellfire Pass and Kanchanaburi War Cemetery in more detail. These sites were a powerful reminder of Australian connections with Thailand, now existing for more than 50 years. It was appropriate that we were able to include these two deeply moving commemorations in our program just before the Australia Remembers activities planned for 1995 and now under way.

In Bangkok we held discussions with a number of government ministers, departments and agencies, as well as such bodies as the UNHCR and the Export-Import Bank of Thailand. In keeping with our parliamentary focus we met with the presiding officers of the Thai parliament, with representatives of its committees and with trade union officials appointed to the Senate by the government.

While we were in Thailand, we had the opportunity to meet with representatives of a number of Australian firms working there. A meeting with members of the Australian-Thai Chamber of Commerce was a particularly good opportunity to find out about how Australian firms operate locally.

While we were in Chiang Mai, we visited an Australian owned and operated factory and received a most useful and detailed briefing. A visit to the lignite mine at Lampang, south of Chiang Mai, showed us a large AIDAB project in action. These business and industrial visits within the program showed us something of another and very important part of Australia's relationship with Thailand.

If there was one thing which impressed itself on the delegation it was the country's perception of its place in the region. This was dealt with in the submission to the inquiry by our own Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, but we were impressed by the frank and detailed way Thai aspirations were expressed. There can be no doubt that Thailand is well positioned to be a dominant political and economic power in the region. Surrounded by Burma, Laos, Cambodia and Malaysia, with Vietnam and south China as near neighbours, there are ample opportunities for Thailand's business and other skills.

The second matter to which I would particularly like to refer is the effort Thailand is making to reform its education system. Many informants stressed Thailand's skill shortages as it grapples with swift modernisation. It was therefore very useful to have had discussions with a senior official at the ministry of education, and the minister for university affairs, before we visited the Klai Kangwol campus of the Rajamangala Institute of Technology and Mahanakorn University of Technology.

The institute is part of a wide network of such bodies and, given its closeness to the resorts of Hua Hin, its courses specialise in training personnel for the tourism and hospitality industry. Rajamangala has an association with the South Australian Department for Education, Training and Further Education, and SAGRIC, that government's international project management arm.

The visit to Mahanakorn showed us something of the operations of a private university in Thailand. Open only five years ago, it specialises in engineering studies. It has a close connection with the University of New South Wales, which has been instrumental in devising its curriculum. The delegation visited Thailand at an important time, just after there had been some controversy over that country's relationship with the Khmer Rouge. On each occasion this matter was raised we were at pains to put the Australian position. The delegation stressed the foreign minister's clarification that he had acted on outdated information and acknowledged the reality and range of problems on a very extensive border.

The delegation also had the opportunity to visit Laos. In 1991 the country began the process of reform by adopting a new constitution. Although we were only in Vientiane for part of a day, we were able to hold discussions with members of the National Assembly, with National Assembly committees and with the chairs of other committees. The delegation was appreciative of the very deep problems the country faces. In 1992 its adult literacy rate was at 55 per cent, its degree of urbanisation was only 20 per cent and it had a life expectancy of only 51 years and an infant mortality rate of 97 per cent. These are the difficulties with which the government currently grapples. Australia is the third largest investor and bilateral donor. This was vital to the delegation's visit. Australia has a major role in the country. That is the reason we thought it was necessary to bring this report forward.

We were told of the range of problems facing Laos, of which the most prominent was its shortage of educationally qualified personnel to allow it to function effectively in a range of international bodies. There is also a range of public health issues which need resolution. With a population of about 4.4 million, it has to face potential problems in retaining its identity, surrounded as it is by much larger neighbours, particularly Thailand. We travelled into and out of Laos across the Friendship Bridge over the Mekong river. This imposing structure was built with Australian funds and expertise. As the report makes clear, there are some problems with the operation of the bridge on the Laos side, in part because of deficiencies in the road system. The delegation was also aware that many of the complaints reflect the realities of any international border.

Whilst in Vientiane we inspected the embassy's facilities, including the clinic, which provides medical treatment to expatriates in Vientiane. This is a valuable service to the entire diplomatic community and to Australian expatriates. The report makes a recommendation about the redevelopment of facilities at the embassy. The delegation was greatly impressed with what it saw in Vientiane and noted the concerns of the National Assembly members to solve the country's problems. The universally high regard in which Australia is held was quite obvious and we believe that Australia has an opportunity to make a valuable contribution to Laos on several fronts. Accordingly, we have recommended that in consultation with the Laotian authorities the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade hold discussions to establish whether Australia might be able to formulate programs to overcome deficiencies in the Lao road system and its health and educational systems.

Whilst not making a recommendation on the subject, we believe that the relationship with Laos and its National Assembly specifically would be enhanced if Australian parliamentary delegations going to the region included the country in their itineraries more regularly than has been the case. The last visit by such a delegation in 1993 was clearly remembered by members of the National Assembly and although it was a very recent visit, admittedly, it was a very rare one. That is something the delegation wants changed.

The program I have outlined during these remarks was seen as integral to the committee's forthcoming and overall report on relations with Thailand. I am sure we did not see everything there was to see in that country. We did make an effort to see something of the operation of Australian businesses and aid funds in various visits and discussions rather than simply be told about things in airconditioned offices in Bangkok.

The delegation was a well-balanced group which carried out a full and interesting program. I would like to thank the other members and particularly the deputy leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Casey, for their support during these visits. I would also mention the secretary who provided throughout very valuable background information, and also extend my thanks for the very strong support—as compared with some other trips I have been on—from the embassy during the visit. I would also like to thank those in the Thai and Laos governments that gave us hospitality and, at the end of the day, gave us a fuller view of the economic and strategic realities of the region. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wholeheartedly endorse the comments made by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and compliment him on his leadership of this very important delegation. I intend, as indicated, to concentrate my remarks this afternoon on what for me—and I believe all other members of the delegation—was a particularly significant experience and a very special element of our official itinerary and duties whilst in Thailand.

PARA.TAB: I refer, of course, to our visits to both Hellfire Pass and the Kanchanaburi War Cemetery. In the time available I would like briefly to set the scene for both places. Hellfire Pass is a cutting through soil and rock on the line of the Burma-Thai railway, which was constructed for the then Imperial Japanese Army during World War II by allied prisoners of war and conscripted Asian labourers.

This cutting was in two sections: one about 500 metres long and about eight metres high; and the other about 80 metres long and about 27 metres high. Much of the work was done by hand—by Australians who were under enormous pressure to complete the task. Their hours of work were lengthened significantly until they reached the literally staggering 18 hours per day; they were forced to keep working at this rate for a period of about six weeks.

For those who were unable to maintain their efforts—and it must be remembered that these men were captives trying to exist under the most appalling conditions—the penalties were indeed horrific. Almost 70 prisoners of war were beaten to death while working in this cutting.

Not far from the pass is the site of what was known as the `Pack of Cards' bridge—so-called because this 400 metres long by 27 metres high structure collapsed three times during construction, 31 men were killed in falls to the rocks below and another 29 were beaten to death.

It is not possible to stand in front of the commemorative plaques in Hellfire Pass and not be conscious of those who laboured, and perished, on this infamous site—people like Sir Edward `Weary' Dunlop, who has since died and whose ashes were scattered there recently; others such as Hugh Clarke who has written so powerfully of the actual work in the pass; or indeed the late Sir Frederick `Black Jack' Galleghan who was so moved by the appalling losses suffered on the railway by the men of the 2nd 30th Battalion that when the survivors returned to Changi, in the words of another prisoner of war, the late Stan Arneil, `the iron man broke down and cried.'

This incident—which serves to illustrate the enormity of the impact of the railway on those forced to build it, and on their mates—is very graphically and movingly described in Arneil's book Black Jack and also in Australians Under Nippon by Hank Nelson and Tim Bowden.

The honourable member for Reid and I laid a wreath from the government and the people of Australia to remind the tourists who visit Hellfire Pass that, despite the passing of the years, this place is remembered and revered by Australians—and always will be.

We then went to Kanchanaburi War Cemetery where the remains of about 7,000 people are interred, including 1,362 Australians who served with our navy, army and air force. The cemetery is beautiful—it belies the horrors of the deaths of those who now rest so peacefully there. At Kanchanaburi we also laid a wreath, and then walked in silence among the graves.

One thing we noticed in both places, but in the cemetery in particular, was the number of Thais who were in the grounds. As the cemetery is on a main road this is far from surprising, but that so many should come to a resting place of foreigners who died in a war that finished 50 years ago was most poignant.

The honourable member for Reid was correct when he observed that it was appropriate that a delegation from this parliament was able to visit Hellfire Pass and Kanchanaburi just before the commencement of the `Australia Remembers' commemorations. The work of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission at places such as Kanchanaburi and the cemetery at Ambon, which I visited with an earlier delegation in 1992, is known and respected.

Such cemeteries are beautiful and deeply moving places to visit, carefully maintained as sacred ground for the remains of those who died in the service of their country. What is perhaps less well known is the work of a subcommittee of the Australia-Thai Chamber of Commerce in Bangkok. This body of enthusiasts has coordinated arrangements for the design, construction and maintenance of a memorial along an abandoned section of the railway line built by the prisoners of war. The way down to the pass is steep and there are now concrete steps and a handrail to assist visitors. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments on the visit by the foreign affairs subcommittee to Thailand and Laos. Like the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), I felt that the visit to Hellfire Pass was a particularly moving experience. It is something I had read about, but I never thought I would experience it. For me it was particularly moving to go where so many Australians and others had suffered so dreadfully. I think it would be a moving experience for anyone to visit that part of Thailand.

PARA.TAB: Like other members of the delegation, I was very impressed with the economic growth of Thailand. This economic growth should not obscure the many difficulties Thailand is facing, not least, I believe, in the areas of transport infrastructure and, indeed, pollution. Sooner or later, countries such as Thailand will have to come to terms with their pollution problem. The longer they leave it, the more difficult it will become. I believe there are openings for Australians with expertise in this field to assist there.

The delegation was in Thailand at a particularly sensitive time in Australia-Thai relations. To say that the Thais are very sensitive to criticism, as indeed are we, real or imagined, is somewhat of an understatement. I believe the delegation helped ease a difficult period in Australia-Thai relations.

There are great opportunities for Australian businesses in Thailand, but the Australian business community in Thailand, or those in Australia intending joint ventures in Thailand, should be aware that the government's role is greater than ensuring expatriate business people continue to earn substantial profits. The government has a wider constituency than just the business community and I believe the government has a role to raise sensitive issues, be it to do with the Khmer or Burmese refugees. We will not and should not turn a blind eye to such issues just because some Australian businesses think it may offend the government and may make a dent in their already substantial profits, or may cause their already substantial profits to suffer.

Having said that, there are ways to raise sensitive issues. The very fact that they are sensitive means they should be raised with great sensitivity. I believe that when questions of great sensitivity were put to the delegation we handled them well. We were not backward in stating Australia's position, but we were very aware of the Thai sensitivity on these issues.

For me, another important aspect was seeing the Friendship Bridge. There has been some criticism in Australia of this bridge, but I believe it is a statement of what Australia can achieve in this part of the world. The bridge was built by Australians and is a testament to what Australia can achieve.

If we wish to achieve other things there, we might be able to assist the Lao government in remedying some of the deficiencies of the road from the bridge into the capital of the country. We had only a day in Lao and that was too short a time to make any meaningful judgment on the issues there. We were greeted with great enthusiasm. The Laos were very impressed that an Australian parliamentary delegation was there, albeit for a very brief time. There are great opportunities there.

In conclusion, the delegation worked well together, which in no small measure was due to the leadership of the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) and the deputy leader, the honourable member for Casey. I welcomed the opportunity to be part of this important delegation. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of my statement, I wish to pay tribute to the leader and the deputy leader of the delegation, and congratulate them on managing a frantic schedule very well. I also pay tribute to the secretary of the committee, Mr Patrick Regan, for the tremendous work he did under very great pressure during the 10 or so days that the delegation was in Thailand.

PARA.TAB: As someone who has had an abiding interest in Thailand for about 25 years, I found these 10 days to be some of the most comprehensive I have ever spent in that country. They brought home to me not only the enormous development that has gone on in that country over the last decade or so but also the incredible opportunities that are available for Australians, should they wish to invest in Thailand or be part of its future development.

Australia and Thailand have always had quite a close relationship, which goes back over many years. It is interesting to see how many people in government, industry and community groups in Thailand have been educated in Australia. That close relationship behoves well for the building of an even closer relationship in the years to come. Obviously, it also provides us with great opportunities if we want to be part of that nation's development.

One of the criticisms we can probably make of Australia's relationship with Thailand over the years—especially in terms of the business community—is that many Australians who have looked at investing in Thailand have never really studied the culture or language of that country. We have heard of representatives from Australian companies who have literally flown into Thailand one night, made a proposition to a business partner and flown out the following night, and wondered why they missed out on it. Thai culture requires a presence to be there, a confidence to be built and a relationship to be cemented—sometimes over many years. I hope that, in years to come, there is a much greater concentration from the Australian side on building those relationships.

There is no doubt that the Thais are doing exactly that. English is now a compulsory subject in virtually all schools in Thailand. The Thais have taken the time to get to understand us and Western civilisation more and more and to take advantage of it. I hope that one of the recommendations of our final report will be to look at ways to bring into the Australian education system a greater understanding and a greater emphasis on the culture and language of Thailand. Quite frankly, if we are going to achieve what we would like to in a country such as that, that must happen.

However, as I said, the relationship has always been fairly close and is becoming closer and closer. Over the last 10 years, we have seen an enormous wave of Australians visiting Thailand for holidays. It has been one of the prime destinations for Australian holiday-makers. Interestingly now, with the emergence of a wealthy middle class in Thailand, the reverse is starting to happen. This year, the growth rate of Thai tourists coming into Australia is in excess of 30 per cent. Around 40,000 Thais will be visiting Australia for holidays. So the system will work both ways. For that reason, we should be looking at a greater emphasis on Thai culture and Thai language in our schools.

The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) made mention of some of the opportunities that Australians could have in terms of pollution control, and those remarks are very true. I sometimes wonder whether we have looked at the real potential of Australian investment and the opportunity for Australians to go to Thailand and to be part of that emerging economy. Certainly pollution control is one such opportunity.

There is an incredible shortage of engineers. The Thai education system is now gearing itself to try to overcome that. But the delegation was told that if every child in school in Thailand today went through university and graduated Thailand still would not have enough qualified people on the ground to handle the development that is being undertaken in that country at the moment.

For a country that does have good relations with Thailand and a country that has connections going back through the education system, we can take great advantage of that either by being part of the education system or by providing qualified personnel to help in this development. I believe this report that is being prepared by the joint committee on foreign affairs, defence and trade is one of the most important undertaken in recent years. I certainly look forward to its conclusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That recognising:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the damage caused to the Australian economy by turbulence in international financial markets through, for example, the increased risks and uncertainties of trade and overseas investment;
(b)the massive anarchic power of the international financial markets to determine and constrain national economic policies;

(c)the value of expanding the domestic tax base so as to reduce the budget deficit and increase resources for desperately needed improvements to human services and infrastructure and so to increase employment; and

(d)the importance also of ensuring a reliable permanent improvement in the financial resources of the UN system so as to enable swift and effective international action to resolve conflict, cope with disasters and support economic and social development—
this House—

(1)supports serious study of the possibility of introducing a small international tax on foreign exchange transactions, widely known as the Tobin tax after the originator of the proposal, Professor James Tobin; and

(2)calls on the Government to (a) cooperate with other countries in initiating such a study which should include support for the establishment of an expert study group under the auspices of the UN and including the IMF and (b) move for the inclusion of this proposal in the declaration of the World Summit for Social Development.

Recent events demonstrate that there is serious disorder in international financial markets. This morning the major financial news relates to the collapse of Barings Bank following speculation in derivatives by one or a few of its dealers. This demonstrates the damage which short-term speculation can do to a corporation. Such speculation is also seriously damaging to countries.

PARA.TAB: Financial markets have been the most powerful constraint on President Clinton's capacity to stimulate economic activity and to increase employment in the US. He won the election having promised to increase employment by eight million, yet was unable to introduce the infrastructure and training programs he had planned because of the limitations imposed on his administration by financial markets.

The anarchic power of international financial markets is one of the principal reasons for concern about the growth of Australia's current account deficit. The larger that deficit, the more vulnerable Australia becomes to the whims of foreign exchange dealers and the more constrained the government becomes to their preferences.

Another effect of this financial market dominance is to impose a deflationary bias onto the global economy. Since the self-interest of financial markets is entirely preoccupied with low inflation, they respond to any spirited signs of economic vitality by urging restraint. Argument for contraction of public outlays—though rarely increases in taxation—plus higher interest rates is their obsessive refrain.

A third aspect of the damage caused by anarchic financial markets is the growth of exchange rate volatility and unpredictability. Since the collapse of the Bretton Woods system, the global financial system has gone through waves of instability during which the exchange rates of major and minor currencies have passed well beyond rates justified by economic conditions. Both this overshooting and the constant smaller movements in exchange rates impose greater costs and risks on trade in goods and services and on international investment. Even though hedging reduces the risk, it is not costless.

Rather than liberating national monetary policy for use as a domestic policy instrument, as was also said to be a benefit of floating, monetary policy has become even more tightly constrained. Interest rates now commonly have to be set to placate the markets, not to encourage economic development let alone growth of employment.

Financial transactions rather than trade now dominate most countries' balance of payments. According to the Bank for International Settlements, BIS, daily net turnover was close to $US900 billion in April 1992—which is around $1,200 billion or $1,300 billion—almost three times its value in 1986 and around 12 times the combined GDP of OECD countries on an annualised basis. Only about five per cent of this relates to trade and longer term investment.

Not only the unemployed in Australia but also, very recently, the people of Mexico are partly the victims of international financial markets. The collapse in the value of the peso is forcing the introduction of sharp cuts in wages and of increases in mortgage interest rates to 48 per cent in some cases. Mexican living standards have been slashed in order to justify the international reserve package, which has been introduced, and to reassure the markets.

It is ironic, by the way, that this US government and IMF rescue package of $US50 billion is being justified by Camdessus, the head of the IMF, as necessary to ensure continuation of `market-oriented approaches the IMF has been promoting in countries such as Mexico'. The biggest government rescue package in history is being justified by the need to enhance the market even further—when market failure is so demonstrably part of the cause of the problem.

The secretary of the Campbell committee, which recommended the deregulation of the Australian financial system in the early 1980s, said recently that `financial markets have become a frankenstein monster which is devouring us'. Fortunately, policies are available which would at least reduce the damage.

A combination of policies is certainly required which would effectively reduce the influence of financial markets and the risks of instability or even of crisis. Amongst these, strengthened disclosure requirements, accounting standards and prudential controls are certain to be a part. Another, which has much to commend it, is a small multilateral tax on foreign exchange transactions.

This proposal by the Nobel laureate in economics, Professor James Tobin, has two basic motivations. He writes: . . . one is to increase the weight that market participants give to long-range fundamentals relative to immediate speculative opportunities. The second is to allow greater autonomy to national monetary policies by making possible greater differences between short-term interest rates in different currencies.

SPEECH.PARA: Increasing the cost of short-term speculative transactions would reduce the extent of exchange rate fluctuations. The tax could be set at a rate which would be too small to deter trade or movements of investment capital but which would penalise short-term speculation. By reducing the potential return to foreign exchange speculation, the tax would discourage the wasteful application of skilled personnel and scarce capital to such activity.

PARA.TAB: The principal criticism of the proposal relates to the difficulty of achieving agreement amongst all major countries involved in foreign exchange dealing. Yet in the late 1980s the Bank for International Settlements succeeded in achieving agreement between countries to set increased prudential reserve ratios for commercial banks. Since the tax would be of benefit to everyone, except foreign exchange dealers and the companies for which they work, such agreement could well be possible.

Governments would benefit from the greater capacity for discretionary monetary policy, from the reduction in interference in national policy by financial dealers and from the additional revenue. The tax is electorally popular: few people like speculators. In US jargon, this is a tax on Wall Street, not on `Main Street'.

Part of the revenue could also be used for establishing a permanent, reliable source of funding for the United Nations system at last. The extent of this automatic funding would have to be settled at the time the administrative arrangements for the tax are negotiated and would no doubt depend in part on the tax rate.

If the tax was set at 0.1 per cent, the volume of transactions fell by a quarter as a result and 10 per cent of the revenue was allocated to the UN, receipts for multilateral purposes would total around $US10 billion annually, after allowing for some exemptions and evasion. Revenue received by the UN could be used for disaster relief, security and development. Surely it is desirable that the UN should have an automatic source of funding for those enormously important tasks rather than having to go around to governments cap in hand every time there is a disaster.

The question for business is whether the benefits for trade and investment from reduced exchange rate volatility, reduced investment risk and improved economic policy making would be sufficient to offset the cost of paying the tax. This also depends in part on the rate at which the tax is set. Tobin suggested a rate of 0.5 per cent. Others consider this too high and have suggested anywhere between 0.01 and 0.25 per cent. It does seem likely that there would be some rate at which the benefits for business might well offset the cost.

Support for a foreign exchange transaction levy is growing; for example, amongst prominent US economists, multilateral agencies such as the ILO, the UNDP and the Commission on Global Governance, and some governments. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) canvassed this idea at the General Assembly early in October last year, and a motion was passed by the national conference of the Australian Labor Party that encourages the government to advocate international study of the idea.

The World Summit for Social Development, which is being held next week, offers an opportunity to take the idea further. The draft program of action proposed study of `new and innovative forms of funding' for the UN, and no government dissented from that recommendation. This will certainly include study of a foreign exchange transaction levy.

A levy such as this seems the best available option for reducing the power of financial markets, reducing exchange rate volatility and raising revenue for high priority domestic and international economic, social and security programs. These are all necessary conditions for an effective reduction of poverty, faster growth of employment and stronger social integration.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—We in the coalition are opposed to the introduction of an international tax on foreign exchange transactions, commonly referred to as a securities transactions tax—STT—as proposed by Professor Tobin of Yale University and advocated in this place by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). I point out that the use of taxes and fees in an attempt to reduce excess speculation has a long history in the United States and was first proposed in 1863. It has obviously not been enthusiastically received.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of compelling arguments for rejection of an STT. First and foremost, the proposed tax would considerably reduce Australia's sovereignty. The most recent proponent of the proposal, Professor Tobin of Yale University, proposes that the tax proceeds would go to the World Bank. However, we in the coalition would be opposed to cede our sovereignty to a supranational authority.

We are opposed to ceding control over monetary policy which reflects Australians' interest and priorities to a supranational institution which could make decisions contrary to Australia's national interest, to our policy traditions and, above all, to our definitions of our national and economic interests.

Second, we reject the radical nature of this proposal. We believe that the transfer of sovereignty to the United Nations should not be contemplated. Support for the establishment of a study group under United Nations auspices would, on probabilities, facilitate and eventually legitimise the emergence of the UN with a new central role in international finance and banking. Such a transfer of sovereignty should not be entertained by Australia.

Third, the proposed tax, like all utopian proposals, is severely impractical. The proponents of an STT argue that it would reduce excessive volatility in financial markets. However, defining excessive volatility is a value judgment. It is difficult to precisely determine the fundamental value of a security. At best, we can estimate. However, without such knowledge, we cannot determine excessive volatility. Furthermore, excessive volatility is more likely to be episodic and not a permanent feature of financial markets. The world-wide stock market crash in 1987 was not alleviated by an STT, despite the fact that most industrialised nations at that time, including Japan and the United Kingdom, had an STT.
Empirical studies have demonstrated that, first, an STT cannot be used with confidence as an effective policy instrument and that, second, other factors being equal, an STT may increase volatility.

Fourth, an STT would harm all investors. The cost of capital could rise. With falling stock prices, it would be more costly for firms to raise capital through issuing stock. An increase in the cost of capital would reduce the amount of business fixed investment and make it more expensive to raise funds in the stock market. All traders would have to pay more each time they traded.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't listened to the proposal.

—You might not like the arguments that have been raised in opposition to it. Since stock prices would fall after the introduction of an STT, all stock holders would be adversely affected. Each investor would have to calculate the payable tax when selling the security. The price to the subsequent seller will also be reduced as further tax will have to be paid.

PARA.TAB: Fifth, a foreign substitution problem would arise. Individuals could avoid the STT by changing what and where they traded—from securities that are taxed to securities that are not taxed, and from securities that are highly taxed to those that are lightly taxed. West Germany, Norway, the Netherlands and Sweden are scrapping their transaction taxes, partly because these taxes resulted in a substantial shift of business to the London market.

The case of Sweden is instructive. No doubt Sweden, as the preferred socio-economic model of the honourable member for Fraser and many of his colleagues, should be of particular interest. In 1986, Sweden introduced an STT for political reasons, at the request of the labour sector. The results were calamitous. Sixty per cent of trading activity shifted to London. Capital gains tax revenue fell so much in response to lower trading that gains from the tax were offset. Trading in Swedish public debt was so adversely affected that taxes on bond trading were eventually removed. There was a dramatic drop in trading volumes. The interest rate options market evaporated. Sweden subsequently abolished its tax in 1992.

The administrative problems of the tax have been noted by leading US authorities. In 1991, the Congressional Budget Office admitted that an STT would be exceedingly difficult to administer and that it would be difficult to tax foreign transactions. In 1990, the US House of Representatives joint committee on taxation declared that the tax would create administrative problems, with the potential to distort the US capital market to the detriment of private industry and the investment public. Financial firms would be given further incentive to design new STT tax exempt securities. There would be massive compliance problems.

In summary, given the intrinsic difficulties in designing a broad based tax that is not easily avoided, it is not surprising that no nation is considering an STT or even increasing its pre-existing STT. As the total value of global currency exchanges was some $US280 trillion in 1992, we can appreciate the administrative problems involved in devising and administering such a tax. It would be an administrative nightmare.

I turn to the proposal referred to earlier by the honourable member for Fraser for the establishment of an STT by a UN study group under UN auspices—including the International Monetary Fund—which is to be discussed at the UN World Summit for Social Development in March 1995.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is to be congratulated on rejecting, at first, the entreaties of his senior colleagues—including those of the foreign minister, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe)—to attend this meeting. The Prime Minister was obviously aware that the United Nations, fresh from its recent dubious successes in solving the Bosnian and Somalian conflicts, has nothing to offer Australia in relation to this issue. For once he was correct, but evidently he lacked the failure of his original convictions and now, reportedly, plans to attend the UN summit. We can only, in this House, take the opportunity to congratulate him on this rare and temporary lapse into good judgment. Perhaps the member for Fraser could, at the appropriate time, inform the House of the obviously substantive differences he has with the Prime Minister on this particular issue.

Finally, the honourable member for Fraser refers to the damage done to the Australian economy by the international financial market turbulence. I would suggest, in conclusion, that the honourable member for Fraser focus his attention on the damage done to Australia by the incurring of a net foreign debt of, still, over $160 billion under the federal Labor government. That directly productive task should concentrate his attention wonderfully and more productively.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence by reminding the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) that the tax which is the subject of this motion is a tax on international transactions only. Most of his comments obviously related to taxes on domestic transactions. Quite clearly, I think we on this side would accept that, where we have a tax on transactions imposed in one country in ultimately what is an internationalised market, that has potential implications elsewhere. But we are talking here about an international tax, a tax on transactions across the globe. Until such time as we have a Mars stock exchange or a Jupiter stock exchange, it will be rather difficult for that tax to be avoided in the same way as the examples in Sweden and the like to which he referred.

PARA.TAB: I think it is also worth pointing out that the motion proposes simply that the issue be studied, that the proposition be seriously examined and that the Australian government cooperate with and assist in such study. Yes, obviously there is a degree of idealism associated with this proposition—but that idealism is heading in the same direction in which the reality of world economics is heading. Many propositions throughout human history that have been idealistic at a certain point have ultimately come to pass as practical reality maybe a generation or two later. When we see the speed of change that is occurring in our world, I think it is worth while for us to give serious consideration to these issues.

It is notable that people of such stature as the President of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, have actually advocated serious consideration of the so-called Tobin tax. In Euromoney only about a year and a half ago, Hans Tietmeyer was quoted as saying that there was a great need for more regulation of international financial flows and that it was important in order to protect the European monetary system. The proposal is designed to increase the influence of long-term fundamental economic factors, underlying factors of productivity and comparative advantage and the like, as against the inevitable impact of short-term speculative influences that have increased enormously over the past 10 or 15 years in the international economic system.

As a result of the introduction of new technology, including electronic technology and the like, the ability to trade vast sums of money almost instantaneously has greatly increased speculative flows. The suggested transaction tax of Professor Tobin—and I quote him—`is designed to make international money markets compatible with modest national autonomy in monetary and macro-economic policy.' I will refer again in greater response to the comments of the honourable member for Deakin on that point.

The tax proposed by Professor Tobin was something like half a per cent. Various alternatives have been suggested but that is probably the highest alternative; others have been 0.1 per cent of the amount traded. It is estimated by Professor Tobin that half a per cent tax on currency transactions would make a four per cent difference in annual interest rates on three-month bills.

The notion of proceeds going to the World Bank from such a tax is obviously a fairly radical suggestion, but I think in the long term we will end up with international institutions that have a tax base that extends beyond the whims of the individual governments that are ultimately linked to those institutions. Through international transactions is one of the more obvious ways of doing it. I do not see why we should suddenly clothe ourselves in paranoia about one world government and descend into the backblocks of Alabama or whatever and start parroting those cries just because these sorts of suggestions are being considered.

Speculation is a problem. Go to any manufacturer in Melbourne and ask how important the value of the Australian dollar is to them. When we go and talk with people in some of the commodity industries we find the same thing: a volatile dollar is a serious problem for people who are trading. Something that is desperately needed by our industries, and I am sure the same applies to industries in other countries, more than just about anything else is a stable currency regime.

What is the key reason we no longer have a stable currency regime? It is not only because the dollar has been floated; there are also the gains that are to be made and the technology which permits those gains to be made by short-term speculation. Clearly it is very difficult in an open international economy to eliminate speculation, but I think there is a fairly strong argument to suggest that the amount of speculation that does occur is out of proportion to what should be permitted in a real economic situation and that taxation is the legitimate device—and in this instance it has to be international.I accept the point that was made by the honourable member for Deakin that purely on a national basis that sort of thing is almost certainly doomed to fail, and therefore it has to be on an international basis in order to shift it back more towards the fundamentals.

The real question is how much productive energy in societies such as ours is actually going into speculation. To what extent do we have firms like AWA investing lots of energy, lots of talent and ultimately lots of money in playing the currency market rather than in concentrating on its core business of producing the products it is supposedly good at?

The Bretton Woods agreement established the basis for the control of international financial flows effectively for about 50 years, but it is quite clear now that we have such a radically different international monetary system that a new international framework needs to evolve, one with less volatility and one where speculation does not completely dominate as—certainly it is arguable—it does today.

It is worth pointing out that on the question of international treaties honourable members opposite tend to foam at the mouth a bit whenever the federal government legislates on the basis of international treaties, but there is an underlying reality as to why Australia is more and more relying on international treaties as the basis for legislation. That is because life itself is becoming more international; the world is becoming increasingly international; and it is therefore only logical that government activity will be increasingly internationally interdependent, and this is precisely what this proposition reflects.

All one has to do is look back to Australia 100 years ago and recall that it was common to have tariffs between the then colonies. There were tariffs on goods transferring between New South Wales and Victoria. Think how ludicrous, ridiculous and difficult to enforce that would be now. What has happened, of course, is that the effective boundaries of economic and social activity, not only in this country but across the world, have spread enormously. Therefore regulation, taxation and all forms of government activity are inexorably being pushed in the same direction.

That is why, if we want to tackle this problem of excessive speculation, it has to be done internationally. That is why we are seeing moves—however difficult, however much beset with problems—towards a single European currency. It is for exactly the same reasons. Ultimately that will come about. It may not be next year or the year after, but eventually there will be a single European currency and those sorts of movements will all go in the one direction.

There is the Internet, from which a whole array of issues will emerge. There is the possibility of the emergence of an Internet currency that would be separate from all the world currencies. People would exchange services on the Internet and pay for them ultimately through some sort of barter system. All sorts of international taxation and regulatory issues will emerge from that.

This tax would not reduce Australia's sovereignty or the sovereignty of any countries across the world. It would not involve us ceding control over monetary policy. Ironically, it would enhance the impact of domestic monetary policy, because the balance of influence that is currently being taken away from national governments by unrestricted speculation and international financial flows would be tilted back in favour of national governments. So the incentive for that speculation, which ultimately has such an enormous influence on what goes on in national economies, would be reduced. Therefore, the level of speculation would be reduced and the power of national governments would be increased, ironic as it may seem.

Merely looking at the issue does not legitimise it automatically, as the honourable member for Deakin suggested. Certainly it accords it with some seriousness. People of the stature of Professor Tobin and Professor Richard Cooper from Harvard and the head of the Bundesbank are saying that we have to look at it. It is being considered, irrespective of whether we like it or not. If we want to be part of the legitimate international debate on issues such as this, it is perfectly appropriate for us to consider it.

My final point, which relates to the final point of the honourable member for Deakin, concerns the United Nations world summit on social development. No doubt the honourable member for Deakin sees this as some sort of KGB conspiracy, the one world government conspiracy surfacing again or perhaps the Fabian Society. Virtually all the heads of government in our region will be there, so no doubt he had better get on the phone to the prime ministers and presidents of Indonesia, Japan, China and Malaysia and so forth and point out the lack of wisdom in their participating. In my view, we would look foolish if our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pulled out from participating. Poverty and social development issues are international in character, as are questions of speculation and economic flows across countries. We should be there and participate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We should see this motion for what it is. It is a proposal that Australia involve itself in the world stage as an advocate for the study of a new tax on international financial transactions. It suggests that Australia put itself in a position where it would be seen to be not realising the full implications of such a proposal.

PARA.TAB: The first point is that trillions of dollars are traded on international money markets throughout the year. It is typical of Labor members to advocate a levy on this source of funding in order for them to find the solution to the United Nations' financial dilemma. Whilst I fully support the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in his zeal to find more responsible funding for the United Nations, because it is in turmoil in its 50th year, there are, in my view, disgraceful indications of a lack of financial responsibility by some of its members. There are considerable defaults by members of the United Nations in their contributions. So I do not for one moment resile from the fact that Australia should be in the thick of it in advocating that members honour their responsibilities and not leave it to a few to carry the burden of all the work that needs to be done in this world. Let me not conceal my zeal for that debate.

Putting Australia in the position on the international stage of saying that the solution to the UN's administration and its future programs can be found by sourcing a vast funding base from international money transactions is, in my view, very naive and dangerous. That would only cement some of the inefficiencies of the UN of which we know. If the UN does not seek to convince each member every three or five years about its programs and has to put up good management propositions, and if the UN simply relies on this huge resource of permanent funding from a levy on international money transactions, I predict that we will get more chaos and bad decision making from the UN.

Members are already opting out of their responsibilities in UN financial terms. They will further opt out simply because the focus will be off their not making annual contributions to particular projects. They will be able to say, `All your funding is provided out of the international funding levy.' Let us not be disillusioned by that.

The second point I want to make is that it is somewhat ironic that senior members of the government, the Labor Party, are here today advocating that Australia involve itself in high level advocacy of this new international tax at a time when they have just backed off from the proposal to introduce a carbon tax, which also stems from international discussions. For the life of me I cannot accept that the government's abandonment of the carbon tax is a permanent abandonment at all; I think it has just been put aside for the time being.

So here we have another illustration of the Labor government looking for revenue the easy way instead of being fully accountable. This Labor government campaigned against the coalition and against a GST, a levy on sales and services. It did so with great vigour and great misrepresentation, I might remind honourable members. Now we have two senior members of the Labor government advocating a new form of levy, this time on trillions of dollars in international money terms.

What we really need is for Labor members, particularly senior members, to be taking their Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Treasurer (Mr Willis) to account and making them address the very serious current account deficit of $26 billion and the net debt in excess of $160 billion, which has risen at astronomical and frightening levels and which is going to rob our children of their heritage because of the huge costs of servicing and repaying such a large debt. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this government has increased its expenditure by about 20 per cent in the last 12 months, at a time when all state and local governments, businesses—large and small—and families have had to pull in their belts as a consequence of the recession which the Prime Minister caused Australia to go into at such deep and painful levels.

There are other practical reasons for me warning the parliament about this proposal and urging it not to fall for the trick of getting involved as an advocate in high level negotiations overseas. The first is that the international tax is recognised as one that could have many harmful side effects and that the benefits that are glibly referred to are sweeping under the carpet the real adverse effects on our nation. The first adverse effect of a financial tax or levy would be to penalise all investors, large and small—not just short-term traders and speculators but also people in the real business of business and of saving for retirement. The cost of capital actually would rise.

If the honourable member does not agree with me about Australia's impending crisis, then I would like to remind him that it is recognised in the OECD that one of the greatest problems that will be facing all nations in the world, particularly Australia, by the turn of the century is the serious shortage of capital in the world. Australia as a very small nation is one of those countries which will feel this more and more—more than anyone else. The consequent increase in the cost of getting capital will inflict on Australia higher costs of interest, service charges and acquisition fees. This tax adds to the cost of all of those things.

So the government is really sentencing us to more costs and more problems in trying to get this nation back on its feet financially. It penalises all investors, not just short-term traders. The fact is that all of these costs are added by the traders and must be borne by the ultimate person who borrows. That is the fact of life. Those on the other side are trying to put onto small business, medium business, large business, local government, hospitals and all of us who are trying to get infrastructure going in Australia an additional cost.

What we should be advocating is a lowering of costs and ways to do that. This levy will not lower costs; it will increase costs. The hedging costs of investors and traders are always added to the price of the borrowed dollar. Ultimately, Australia, as a large borrower, due largely to the government's mismanagement over the last 12 years, will have to pay a greater share. That is beyond argument, in my view.

Another point is that a lot of Australia's savings are in mutual funds, such as AMP and National Mutual. We are looking at them changing. Perhaps they will; perhaps they will be floated. It is a fact of life that Australia's householders have saved very heavily in mutual funds. Mutual funds, for the information of the honourable member on the other side, the honourable member for Fraser, if he does not realise this, by their very nature are one of the largest traders in international currency. They handle vast sums of money. Every day they incur substantial trading costs.

What my friend is doing is saying to all the policyholders of AMP and National Mutual, `I want to add to your costs, and therefore reduce your returns, your bonuses and your accumulated benefits, by putting this burden on you.' That is a fact of life. He is trying to put another cost on the small people, the little people, of Australia. I am sure he does not realise that that is what he is doing, but the fact is that that is the consequence of it.

There is another problem, and it relates to stock prices. Stock exchange prices would certainly fall. Many commentators say that, after the introduction of the international levy, stock prices would fall from 2.3 per cent to five per cent. Stock prices have already moved lower this year because of the fear about the government's mismanagement of the economy, the rising current account deficit, increasing interest rates and the failure of the government to address its fiscal and monetary policies. So we have real problems there, and we have another one being advocated. God help Australia. Heaven forbid!

I mentioned that the cost of capital at the turn of the century would be a larger problem for Australia than for most other nations. If we have accompanying that particular phenomenon falling stock prices, it will be more costly for firms to raise capital. I urge honourable members not to fall for this trick. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House acknowledges the need for more research into prostate cancer and that money be allocated for a major education program targeting Australian males.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving this motion, I have a simple message for all the men in this parliament: if you live long enough, you will end up with a prostate problem. I have a simple message for every Australian male: if you live long enough, you will end up with a prostate problem as well. You may not get prostate cancer but, if you live long enough, you will end up with a prostate problem. I did. I had surgery last December in Prince Henry Hospital. I am announcing that not because I think anybody is interested in what happened with my prostate but as part of the job we have to do to raise the awareness of Australian men so that they are prepared to talk about it, to understand it and to take action about it. I pay tribute to the surgeon Dr Robert Farnsworth, the head of the urology department at Prince Henry Hospital—an excellent man.

PARA.TAB: There is male fear. There is a reluctance to talk about prostate problems. The prostate can become engaged with three problems: first, prostatitis, which is basically an infection caused by bacteria and which is fixed by antibiotics, so for our purposes we will not worry about that particularly; second, enlargement of the prostate with benign prostatic hyperplasia, BPH; and, third, prostate cancer.

Both BPH and prostate cancer occur usually in males older than 50 years. The older you are, the more likely you are to develop BPH or prostate cancer. Prostate cancer grows very slowly. There is histological evidence of prostate cancer of no great significance during their lifetime in 30 per cent of males over the age of 50 years, but 80 per cent of males over the age of 80 years have the same histological evidence of prostate cancer. Australian males have a one in 23 chance of developing prostate cancer in their lifetime and a one in 70 chance of dying from it before the age of 75.

Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer—after lung cancer—occurring in Australian men in terms of incidence and mortality. What is the prostate? The Cancer Dictionary defines the prostate as:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the male sex glands located just below the bladder and in front of the rectum. It is about the size of a walnut and is wrapped around part of the urethra. It produces fluid that becomes part of the semen.
When I talk to young men, old men and middle-aged men I am constantly amazed that they do not know what the prostate is, they do not know where it is and they do not know what it does.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the motion calls for more funding for education. What is BPH? The prostate increases in size as we age. The BPH affects approximately 50 per cent of all men over 50 years of age. We do not know why it grows; we need research to find out. Australian men need to know the symptoms. In December, when I was recuperating from surgery, I was visited by some friends. One man said to me, `Yes, I have got all of those symptoms, but I am too scared to go to the doctor.' The symptoms are: delay in beginning urination; lack of pressure when urinating; dribbling at the end of urination; urinary infection; increased urge to urinate at night; sudden blockage of urine flow; urgency; and retention of urine in the bladder.
I say to the men of Australia: if you have any of those symptoms see your doctor. Do not leave it. Do not let it go. Do not be fearful. Find out and get treatment.

Only one per cent of cases of prostate cancer are detected in men under 50 years of age, but 50 per cent of men over the age of 70 have prostate cancer. The Cancer Dictionary says that `not much is known about the causes of prostate cancer'. We need to know. We need research. In a paper released by Pienta and Esper we see the statement `a definitive cause for prostate cancer has not been established'.

It is worth while comparing the incidence of breast cancer, cervical cancer and prostate cancer. In 1988, breast cancer was diagnosed in 6,542 women and 54 men; cervical cancer was diagnosed in 1,061 women; prostate cancer was diagnosed in 4,566 men; and 354 men had cancer of the testes. In 1991, 6,261 men were found to have prostate cancer. In 1993, 2,641 women died from breast cancer, 317 women died from cervical cancer and 2,544 men died from prostate cancer.

It is interesting to compare the funding for screening and research. I will not go into the details, but from 1991-92 research and screening for breast cancer has accounted for $322,370,000; research and screening for cervical cancer has accounted for $23,560,000; and the total for prostate cancer research was only $661,765. I do not begrudge 1c of the money that has gone into research and screening for breast cancer and cervical cancer. I merely make the comparison and point out that the males of Australia are lagging behind in the amount of money available for research.

The diagnosis of prostate cancer involves three main procedures. The first of these is digital rectal examination. This is the most common procedure where the doctor puts a rubber glove on his hand, puts a finger up the rectum and has a feel around. It is not a particularly attractive test for most men, and it is not particularly sensitive. In an article by Whelan entitled `What they don't tell you about prostate cancer' it is said that `thirty to 60 per cent of men with prostate cancer have tumours that the examining physician cannot feel'. It is simply not enough to have the digital rectal examination.

The second procedure is prostate specific antigen—PSA. This is a blood test that measures a substance—PSA—which is secreted only by the prostate. An elevated level of PSA may indicate cancer, but it can also be elevated in benign prostatic hypoplasia as well. However, a recently published large-scale study by Gann et al, which measured PSA levels in blood samples taken from participants upon their entry to the Physicians' Health Study (US) in 1982 and analysed 366 of these men who were eventually diagnosed with prostate cancer, found that a single PSA measurement had a `relatively high sensitivity and specificity for detection of prostate cancer that arose within four years'. The authors concluded, `PSA has the highest validity of any circulating cancer screening marker discovered thus far.'

The third is transrectal ultrasound, which involves the insertion of an ultrasound probe into the rectum and sound waves bouncing off the prostate. This is not usually used as an initial test, rather for confirmation. It should be pointed out that the only definitive diagnosis of prostate cancer is by biopsy.

There is controversy over the thought of having screening programs. The American Cancer Society and the American Urological Association recommend that all men over 50 years of age have a digital rectum examination and a PSA test each year. In Australia the National Health and Medical Research Council is reviewing evidence for and against prostate cancer screening, but the Australian Cancer Society has recommended in guidelines released in December 1994 against screening men without symptoms. I seek leave to incorporate the position of the Australian Cancer Society on screening.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Leave is granted, subject to the document meeting the Speaker's guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last point in relation to that is that men with symptoms suggestive of benign or malignant prostatic disease should be assessed by a medical practitioner. I come back to the point that any male who has symptoms must see his doctor as soon as possible. We should also note that the symptoms of prostate cancer are similar to BPH. But men should not take a risk. If they are over 50 and have any symptoms they should see their doctor as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: Prostate cancer has not been the subject of a major focus for research. In fact, a recent article in the New Scientist said that the disease has been underresearched and underfunded. That is absolutely true. Much is uncertain about it. Much is unknown. More research is needed. I seek leave to incorporate the December 1994 guidelines of the Australian Cancer Society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is granted, subject to the document meeting the Speaker's guidelines.

—There are two issues to my motion: the need for more research and for more education. We do not know what causes the prostate to enlarge—we need more research. We do not know what causes prostate cancer—we need more research. Australian men are ignorant about the prostate—they need education about it. Australian men are fearful—they need education about it. Many, as I said before, do not know where their prostate is, they do not know what it does and they need to know. We need to inform Australian men and the Australian public in general on what is happening with prostate cancer and we need more research.
—Is the motion seconded?

—I second the motion and am pleased to support it. According to the Cecil Textbook of Medicine, the prostate is the second leading site of cancer in males—although I think in Australia it is the third leading site of cancer in males—accounting for about 19 per cent of all male cancers. The only female cancer that accounts for more new cancer cases per year is cancer of the breast. The figures that the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) has given in his excellent argument show that the number of people who suffer from prostate cancer is about two-thirds of the number of people who suffer from breast cancer.

PARA.TAB: We should have research, but we also should admit that whether all information about research ought to be released is a subject for debate, particularly in the case of breast cancer. Just recently I noticed on a science program that there was some argument that some of the information given to women about breast cancer has been misleading to them and has sometimes been misused. My view is that this is not a case for suppressing information about research to adults in the community, wherever they are. The old idea of hiding information from people has not worked all that well. Perhaps we ought to present information better and more clearly, but we certainly should not suppress information.

Approximately 8.7 per cent of white males and 9.4 per cent of non-white males will develop cancer of the prostate. It is calculated that 2.6 per cent of newborn white males and 4.3 per cent of newborn non-white males will eventually die of the disease. Carcinoma of the prostate, interestingly, does not develop in eunuchs, but there is no other evidence to suggest that a direct relationship exists between hormone levels and the development of prostatic cancer. Similarly, no relationship between the development of benign prostatic hyperplasia and prostatic cancer has been demonstrated.

Furthermore, according to Cecil, there is little relationship between prostatic cancer and industrial carcinogens, cigarette smoking, use of alcohol, disease patterns, circumcision, weight, height, blood group or hair distribution. Perhaps I have gone a bit further than the honourable member for Cowper in that area. Just because he has suffered the disease does not mean that I will because I am balder.

As carcinoma of the prostate progresses, the tumour can extend to other areas, as happens with most cancers. It can extend to the urethra, the bladder neck, the seminal vesicles, and the trigone. But perhaps I have said enough about the medical aspects of cancer of the prostate.

I now want to extend what the honourable member for Cowper has said on a couple of issues. Firstly, I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 January where, under guidelines which were to be released this month by the nation's peak cancer body, the Australian Cancer Society, it was indicated that testing all men over 50 for prostate cancer may do more harm than good. That may well be true. I do not want to enter into that debate. I mention it simply to make clear that the motion is calling for more research; it is not necessarily calling for more screening. Debate ought to continue and the need for screening ought to be clarified. Some recent methods have been developed which may not require the sort of rectal examination that the honourable member for Cowper talked about. If we can get to that stage, maybe we can have relatively safe screening.

My own belief is that anything that involves the sort of procedures associated with screening at the moment ought to be very carefully considered, particularly for older men. After all, it is once men reach middle age that the tendency towards prostatic cancer increases. Dr Jeanette Ward, who helped prepare the guidelines that I mentioned, has said that there is no evidence that early detection reduced deaths. I believe that ought to be good enough for us at this time. Until there are better methods, we should be careful about the amount of screening we do.

But that is no argument against further research.I believe that the amount of research that is being done could be increased. For instance, the National Health and Medical Research Council spent $341,765 in 1994, but $320,000 was provided to support other research projects. Prostate cancer has not been a major focus for research funding. Second only in incidence to breast cancer, it ought to be receiving more funding. The New Scientist recently said that the disease has been underresearched and underfunded.

In December 1994 the Australian Cancer Society identified some urgent areas for research. They include: contributing to international efforts to evaluate the outcomes of prostatic cancer screenings using community based randomised trials; rigorous evaluation of the sensitivity, specificity, negative and positive predicative values of alternative tests in community populations; assessment of men's attitudes to prostate cancer, their views on the purposes and limitation of screening programs, and the value they place on years of life lost through malignant prostate disease compared with other significant causes of death and disability among men.

As the honourable member for Cowper said, we need more awareness among people of prostate cancer. I have had letters from women expressing concern about the amount of research that is being undertaken into prostatic cancer.

Another area for research is the need for assessment of the views of general practitioners, urologists, pathologists and radiation oncologists about prostate cancer screening and their preferred sources of information and current practices to assess how widespread unproven screening activity has become. We cannot just say that screening is pointless; we ought to be assessing how widespread the unproven activity has become.

Another area which would be very useful is the design, implementation and controlled evaluation of intervening to defuse public and professional anxiety about prostate cancer screening where it is safe, and particular strategies are needed to reduce unproven screening activity and general practice until there is stronger scientific evidence to support screening.

There needs to be methodological research to measure urological outcomes in prostate cancer management and palliation. There needs to be more systematic evaluation of the management of prostate cancer by stage and age to determine complication rates, the prognosis and the predictors of outcome. It could well be that it is important to do research for the sake of those people who are younger and who have prostate cancer at a reasonably young age as well as those who are older.

Small scale projects are needed to ascertain the feasibility in Australia of follow-up for men with abnormal results should screening at some time prove to be effective. The nature of quality assurance mechanisms and strategies to enhance compliance with repeated screening and follow-up treatment merit some of those types of projects. As well, there could well be the development of more accurate tests to predict prostate cancers which will progress and those which will not.

There have been recent calls for mass screening.
