TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for bringing to the House this motion acknowledging the need for more research into prostate cancer. Many people do not have the foggiest idea of what the prostate is or what it does. To understand the problems surrounding the detection and treatment of prostate cancer it is essential to recognise that this type of cancer in some form is extremely common, particularly as men age, but that it often grows slowly and, in many cases, is not life threatening.

PARA.TAB: However, prostate cancer is the second most common cause of death from cancer in men in most Western countries. Each year more than 2,000 Australians die from prostate cancer and a further 5,000 new cancers are diagnosed. An Australian male has a one in 23 chance of developing prostate cancer during his lifetime and a one in 70 chance of dying from it before the age of 75. Prostate diseases usually occur in men older than 50, although prostatic symptoms are more common before middle age. Prostate cancer is rarely seen in males under 55.

Since the proceedings are being broadcast, I guess it is an idea to identify some of the symptoms associated with prostate cancer: the need to pass urine more frequently and during the night; difficulty in starting urine flow; a slow, interrupted flow and a dribbling afterwards; sudden, strong urges to pass urine; a feeling of not having completely emptied the bladder; and pain or burning during urination.

Research has shown that possible risk factors identified with prostate cancer include: diet—high fat consumption, low green vegetable consumption; genetic—family history of prostate or breast cancer; occupational—in other words, cadmium exposure, radiation exposure; sexual history—a number of sexual partners, frequency of intercourse; medical history—vasectomy, benign prostatic hyperplasia.

With these risk factors known as causes of prostate cancer, the logical solution to reduce the incidence of the cancer is to make men more aware of the condition, especially those who are at an age where they are vulnerable to developing prostate cancer. We should make them aware of some of the measures that can prevent prostate cancer from developing any further. For example, they could learn to control their diet. By eating non-fat foods they can reduce the risk of developing prostate cancer.

Some of the treatments for prostate cancer vary according to the degree of the cancer. Prostate cancer may be treated by surgery, radiotherapy or hormone treatment: medications, including those with hormone levels which relax the prostate; surgery to remove the enlarged part of the prostate; or radiotherapy—that is, laser or microwave and heat treatments. These procedures are still relatively new and need further long-term evaluation. The treatment options available for prostate cancer depend on the grade and stage of the disease as well as the patient's age, life expectancy and general health. It is more likely that the patient will die of other causes than prostate cancer.

Three main procedures can be used as an aid in diagnosis of the prostate cancer: firstly, digital rectal examination or DRE; secondly, prostate specific antigen; and, thirdly, trans-rectal ultrasound. Research indicates that using a combination of the above tests may be a more effective method of diagnosing prostate cancer than using only one method.

There are a number of barriers making this impossible. For example, the golden standard of prostate cancer detection has long been the digital rectal examination or DRE. This is easy to perform and is an inexpensive method which has been rejected by many men. Even though the test can usually be done quickly and with little discomfort, some men will not submit to a rectal examination unless they are having severe problems, usually related to urination.

Clearly, an education program in this area would help things greatly. A campaign targeted at men over 50 to have tests done will benefit those with an early stage of prostate cancer, so that it may be determined as to what is the best treatment for their condition.

The immediate advantages of the prostate specific antigen are that it is objective, quantifiable and more comfortable than the DRE. But even its most enthusiastic supporters recognise that the PSA has limitations. Its results include both false negatives and false positives. A man can have prostate cancer even in an advanced stage and still have a normal PSA reading. From this there is considerable controversy over whether any of the above procedures should be considered for mass screening of men to detect prostate cancer. The cumulative harmful effects of screening many men may outweigh the benefits of earlier diagnosis of the few.

Let me give an analogy. Suppose you wanted to build a fence to keep three types of animals—turtles, birds and rabbits—on your property. The birds would soon be gone, flying over the fence to parts unknown; the turtles would plod around slowly, but none would ever reach the end of the property; and the rabbits would hop around and, eventually, unless you stopped them, clear the fence and escape. In other words, the fence would be effective only for the rabbits. The turtles do not need it and the birds would ignore it.

If we apply this analogy to clinical prostate cancer, the birds are men who are beyond cure because their malignancies have metastasised; the turtles are patients with low grade, non-aggressive, non-life threatening prostate cancer; and the rabbits would be the only ones to gain from the screening. To screen the turtles would cause unnecessary pain and inconvenience and the birds can be treated only with non-surgical assistance to make their lives more comfortable. Treating all the men diagnosed as having prostate cancer, therefore, would mean saving the lives of a third of them, at most, at the cost of some degree of unnecessary incapacitation in twice as many others.

Therefore, what we need is not massive screening but methods of determining which of the prostate confined cancers are real and would benefit from surgery and which of them are harmless and should be left alone. None of the methods practised now absolutely guarantee the results that we need.

It is obvious that more research needs to be done into the causes and various treatments of prostate cancer. Because the procedures now in place do not guarantee detection of prostate cancer or provide the right solution as to what the best treatment might be, mass screening for prostate cancer is not necessarily the answer.

The position of the Australian Cancer Society on prostate cancer screening is contained in the following guidelines: there is insufficient evidence that men's health will be advanced through prostate cancer screening of asymptomatic men; prostate cancer is common and does, to a lesser extent, cause death; no prospective data is available to demonstrate quantifiable and reproducible reductions in death from prostate cancer due to screening of asymptomatic men by PSA or DRE, or both, at any interval—thus PSA or DRE alone, or in combination, cannot yet be recommended as screening tests for asymptomatic men either as a once-off examination or repeated at annual, biennial or some other interval; and men with symptoms suggestive of benign or malignant prostate disease should be assessed by a medical practitioner.

Therefore, we come to the question: what will be the benefit of mass prostate cancer screening for men in Australia? The value of research has been identified by the Australian Cancer Society under the following points: an assessment of men's attitudes towards prostate cancer, their views of the purposes and limitations of screening programs and the value they place on years of life through malignant prostate disease compared to other significant causes of death and disability among men; the design, implementation and controlled evaluation of interventions to diffuse public and professional anxiety about prostate cancer screening in particular; the strategies needed to reduce unproven screening activity in general practice until stronger scientific evidence to support screening is forthcoming.

In 1994 some $320,000 was provided for prostate cancer research. I do not believe that is anywhere near enough. As the current treatments cannot provide absolute answers as to the reasons why men develop prostate cancer and the difference in treatments can have emotional and physical side effects for the patient suffering from prostate cancer, we need to spend more time researching new methods of detection and treatment. The research undertaken so far has provided no evidence that a mass screening project for prostate cancer reduces mortality or increases life expectancy.

Added to the need for research is the need for a major education campaign targeting Australian males over the age of 50 to inform them that they are at risk and that they should consult their doctor for an examination. I hope this motion goes some way towards encouraging men in that age group and those who are asymptomatic to start looking after their health. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Is cure necessary in those for whom it is possible? . . . Is cure possible in those for whom it is necessary?

PARA.TAB: There are important issues: first of all, more specific and therefore better serum markers for the detection of prostate cancer; secondly, improved methods for predicting progression of prostate cancer and the ability to discriminate between latent and clinical tumours; and, thirdly, finding alternatives to conventional forms of hormone therapy. SPEECH.PARA: Prostate cancer is the most commonly diagnosed invasive malignancy of men living in Western countries.

Only with adequate funding will the ongoing debates give way to well grounded consensus.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome the opportunity to speak in support of the motion before the House today, and I too commend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) for raising this issue.

Prostate cancer is a serious health issue for Australian men: 2,544 died from it in 1993. It has never been a disease rating up in the top 10. It has been under-researched and underfunded primarily because it has been seen as a disease affecting older men.

As previous speakers have mentioned, an Australian male has a one in 23 chance of developing prostate cancer during his lifetime and a one in 70 chance of dying from it before the age of 75. In 1988 over 4,500 new cases of this cancer were diagnosed. Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer—for both incidence and mortality—affecting Australian men after lung cancer.

Having recently been part of a House committee hearing into breast cancer, it is interesting to note some similarities when it comes to gaining statistical evidence to support or refute certain positions as to whether one form of treatment is any better than another. Any coherent and up-to-date statistical information often lies buried away in state departments and teaching hospitals across the country. No-one has yet come up with an effective way of collating and making these invaluable statistics available to state and Commonwealth health bureaucrats, hospitals, colleges and, more importantly, the local GPs.

One wonders just how effective our health planning really is if we do not put something as vital as this in place in Australia. It is interesting to note that prostate cancer generally grows very slowly and many men die of other causes, unaware that they have also developed prostate cancer. Research shows that 30 per cent of men over 50 years of age have histological evidence of prostate cancer which was of no significance during their lifetime.

As with most other major health problems facing our society, there is some uncertainty about what risk factors exist for prostate cancer. There is considerable disagreement over the best options for treatment and the cost effectiveness of mass screening for this form of cancer. I read with interest in this month's Australian Medicine in the article headed `Prostate Screening Could Ruin your Life' of concerns expressed by the Urological Society of Australasia on the issue of screening. In its valued judgment, there appears to be no clear benefit from screening for most men, despite a rise in the number of screenings occurring in this part of the world.

However, many people—including many doctors—believe that screening asymptomatic men is the answer to prostate cancer. The cost of such a program would be at least $122 million annually. As previous speakers have stated, the most prominent of risk factors appears to be high levels of dietary fat consumption. Vasectomy also appears to confer an increased risk of developing this disease.

As the other speakers have said, and as the honourable member for Cowper reiterated in great detail, we vitally need a better research and educative program in Australia. This is vital if we hope to address the problems associated with this form of cancer. I, too, commend the motion to the House.

At the time I did not relate that to the issue of prostate cancer. At Maralinga, there is a $120 million program for the nuclear testing program and the clean-up afterwards. So great effort is involved there. I have focused on that matter for many years of my life, as I have lived in the area and have been aware of the royal commission and a whole range of issues surrounding the Maralinga tests. Prostate cancer affects far more people, but I only became aware of it when I did some work on it with the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl).

PARA.TAB: Statistics in 1993 show that deaths from prostate cancer were 2,544 and that deaths from breast cancer were 2,641—a difference of almost 100. I think honourable members have canvassed very well various issues such as the genetic likelihood of getting cancer, diet and the effectiveness of screening.

I join the debate with pleasure to highlight the need for an increased effort on this issue. We need awareness, and we have to discuss the education role and the legislative requirement. I suppose that is what is predominantly under debate. The financial arrangements may end up with some redirection of finance. I encourage the appropriate administrative arrangements which would achieve that. The practical issues will be managed by people much more expert than me. I thought the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) made a very good point. She mentioned the $34 billion that we spend on health. She highlighted the fact that we do not spend anything like what is reasonable in preventative health in that $34 billion.

Apparently we will spend something like $236 million in the next five years on breast cancer. As the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) highlighted, it is not a case of putting one ahead of the other or of one cause being greater than the other; it is perhaps a matter of highlighting an area that has been ignored for too long that is worthy of greater consideration. Prostate cancer is apparently not even listed in the budget index.

As I have already said, breast cancer is the most common cause of death by cancer in Australian women, and prostate cancer is the second for men. Prostate cancer is fought with radiation or the scalpel and, with greater effort, perhaps we may uncover a range of other treatments.

In conclusion, I welcome the opportunity to speak on this matter. I thank the honourable member for Cowper for bringing it to my attention. In the few minutes left to him I hope he will continue to enlighten us on things this parliament might do to improve matters surrounding this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank everybody who has participated in this debate. Speakers on both sides of the House have been thoroughly bipartisan, as they should be, and I hope that Australia will be much better informed as a result of it.

PARA.TAB: One thing I would like to make quite clear is that the condition for which I had surgery in December was not cancerous; I am very lucky. I had the other form of the problem, a benign prostatic hyperplasia, which is an enlargement of the prostate. I think it should be well-known to all Australian males that, once they turn 50, half of them will have an enlarged prostate—so the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who has just turned 50, has a one in two chance of having an enlarged prostate.

While we have been concentrating on the need for research into prostate cancer, allied with that is a very definite need for research into why the prostate enlarges from its normal size, which is about the size of a walnut, to the size of a lemon. That then carries with it the problems we are concerned about.

In my case I became aware of the need for treatment about 20 months ago when I learned that somebody that I knew had had prostate cancer. In his case there was some delay in the diagnosis and, as a result, he lost his testes and suffered the consequent dismay that that would cause any man. In that particular year he ended up having five sessions of surgery. I am highlighting these examples because I think it important for men and women to know what goes on.

I have a relative by marriage in Queensland who is a pathologist, and he gives himself an annual pathology check. At the beginning of last year he did a PSA test and found that it was elevated to six. I might say that my PSA test after surgery was one, which is great. When he found his to be six he went to his GP. His GP did a digital rectal examination and said, `Oh no, that is clear; there is nothing there.' Three months later he did another PSA and found that it was up to seven. He went back to his GP who did another digital rectal examination and said, `She's right; she's clear—nothing there.' Three months later it was up to a PSA of 7.6. This time he insisted on having a biopsy, and the biopsy showed that he had advanced cancer of the prostate.

This is why I urge Australian males, should they have symptoms, to make sure they go to see their GPs. They should not neglect it. Ultimately that particular relative of mine had surgery on 25 October last year. I spoke with him between Christmas and new year when he still had a catheter inserted and he was still wearing a bag strapped to his leg. He too had lost his testes.

This is the sort of problem faced by Australian men, and this is why I am so pleased that everybody who has spoken in this debate did the right thing and challenged all Australian men to take care of themselves and to seek more money for research.

TALK.START.PARA: —The structure of the social security and veterans affairs legislation has the effect of treating many ex-service personnel who served in Australia as second class citizens. These veterans, whether they volunteered or were drafted, served wherever they were sent—it was not a matter of their choice to serve overseas or at home. Yet, eligibility for a service pension is limited to those who served in operations against the enemy on land, sea or air, or in a situation of danger from hostile enemy forces. Those who are not eligible for a service pension from the Department of Veterans' Affairs have found that even a disability pension is counted as income and therefore has the effect of reducing social security pensions. However, under the Veterans Entitlement Act, a disability pension is not regarded as income for service pension assessment purposes. This provision has led to unjust results, such as those for veterans who served in northern Australia, some returning home over land and others by ship.

PARA.TAB: Service personnel returning from northern Australia by ship became eligible for a service pension, which has benefited them financially because the amount of disability pension has no effect on service pension payments. On the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, and with the number of ex-service personnel now reducing, it is time that the government took action to remove these inequities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The technique is called `push polling', which is a technique pioneered by the extreme right wing Republican candidates in the United States. I believe this technique has been employed recently by the Liberal Party of Australia—both in the Northern Territory last year and in the ACT last week—and it works this way: the idea of push polling is to see if certain information can push voters away from the opposition candidate in support of the candidate favoured by the people paying for the poll. I concur with the judgment passed by David S. Broder who exposed this technique in the Washington Post. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Every time you think that the political campaign operatives have hit bottom and you can't find anything sneakier and more underhanded to do, they prove you wrong.

What has happened here is that the Liberal Party has circulated, for reaction, a survey. They have admitted that the survey document was genuine, that it is theirs and that they surveyed 300 to 400 people in the community. The survey was conducted last week by the Roy Morgan Research Centre. The article in the Canberra Times states that Mr Robb, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party, said:
"We asked questions that we understood to be true."

PARA.TAB: Mr Robb said the research had been a "private and confidential" survey designed to give the party a "background feel for community attitudes to this Labor candidate".

ANSWER.PARA: The document is circulated to electors and asks them to make a judgment or to give an indication about certain things. It is claimed that the statements and questions contained in the document are true. I will read some of the questions. On abortion the document says that Sue Robinson has stated that she supports the right to abortion up to nine months of pregnancy. It is untrue; she has never stated that she supports the right to abortion up to nine months of pregnancy. On AIDEX, neither Sue Robinson nor the Canberra ALP—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is her position? Does she have a view on it?
—The member for Berowra will cease interjecting.

—participated in or supported the violent AIDEX demonstration. The Labor Club has never gone bankrupt and is, in fact, trading profitably and having its best year ever. It makes allegations about her association with the issue known as VITAB. She makes clear that she gave full and frank evidence to the committee of inquiry into VITAB and the committee found no evidence of wrongdoing or illegal or improper behaviour on her part. It goes on. At the beginning of the questionnaire are the words, `All of the statements I am going to read to you are true. Let's begin.'

The architect of this outrage, Andrew Robb, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party, should be dismissed or should resign and the Leader of the Opposition, if he is compliant in this technique, should disown it and apologise, or force Mr Robb to resign. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. I refer the minister to the allegations made about CARE Australia on yesterday's Sunday program. What is the minister doing to ensure that CARE Australia is using taxpayer and public donations for the aid activities for which they have been given?

—The concern which the honourable member expresses over the allegations made on the Sunday program is one shared by the government and me personally. We are deeply concerned about those allegations and, in particular, about the effect they might have—were they found to be true—on the whole non-governmental aid sector. As the honourable member knows from my visit to his electorate at the weekend, there are many good people who voluntarily give up their time and money to work for disadvantaged people in poor countries. I would hate to see the trust, which I believe is deserved by those organisations, forfeited as a result of something of this kind.

PARA.TAB: As to the specific allegations mentioned by the honourable member, most of them are currently being investigated as a result of action I took in October and November last year. They are currently being investigated by an independent firm of auditors, BDO Nelson Parkhill. In short, we were quick and thorough in our response to those allegations before they became public. Those allegations were first made by Mr Bernard Broughton in January 1991. At that time, AIDAB conducted a thorough investigation. It informed CARE Australia of the allegations and asked it for a response. As a result of the investigations then carried out, AIDAB was able to identify that at that time CARE Australia held surplus or unexpended funds totalling more than $400,000 in public moneys. Some of those amounts were repaid but the majority was reallocated—with the agreement of the government—to another activity run by CARE Australia.

AIDAB commissioned the New South Wales Auditor-General's office in May 1992 to undertake an audit of CARE Australia's financial regulations and systems, and its ability to meet the stringent requirements which we as a government place on financial reporting and acquittals of government moneys. That audit was finalised in June 1993. It concluded that CARE Australia's controls and systems were reasonable and sufficient to meet adequately disclosure of information guidelines, but it asked for some changes to be made. In view of the uncertainties about whether they would be made and whether they would be adequate, the auditors recommended a follow-up review.

I point out to the House that, at that time, the investigation was hampered by the unwillingness of Mr Broughton to make available any supporting documentation. In May last year, Mr Broughton reiterated his allegations to me and I immediately instructed AIDAB to investigate his claims. I also asked him at that time to hand over any documentation, any evidence, he had. He did so in July 1994 when his files were passed to the auditors, BDO Nelson Parkhill, who were at that time investigating the theft of vegetable oil from another project run by CARE. Those files were also handed over to AIDAB.

In October 1994, and in response to advice from the auditors that the Broughton documents contained sufficient detail to enable the allegations to be investigated by an audit, I approved expanded terms of reference for the audit so that the Broughton allegations could be fully investigated. So there have now been two major audits of CARE's systems. The second is still under way. I am absolutely determined that those allegations will be thoroughly investigated and finally put to bed one way or another.

I inform the House that there will be a meeting tomorrow between the government auditors and CARE Australia. I had a telephone call this morning from the Chairman of CARE Australia, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and he assured me that all documents would be made available to the auditors to ensure that the allegations could be properly looked into. On my instructions AIDAB has contacted Mr Ross Coulthardt, the reporter from the Sunday program, and he has agreed to meet and cooperate fully with the government auditors.

I conclude by making one or two remarks about the general question of accountability of aid organisations for the moneys they receive. As far as the government moneys they receive are concerned, many years ago we put in place requirements for comprehensive reporting on how government funds are spent as well as acquittals of expenditure once it is made. But donations from the public are in a different situation. The use of those donations is covered by a mishmash of laws, basically state legislation, relating to companies and associations. So it is very difficult to arrive at a situation where you can compare, for example, the amount which is spent by different aid organisations on administration. It is difficult to put in place a system of accountability for those donations as to where they are spent and so forth.

Some system of accountability is essential. In September last year, I wrote to the Chairman of the Industry Commission inquiring into charitable organisations, Mr Bill Scales, and asked that the inquiry consider and report on the issues relating to accountability for public donations not only to domestic charities but also to those operating overseas. The draft interim report of the Industry Commission went into that issue in some detail. I again wrote to the Chairman of the Industry Commission on 17 February 1995 and said that—

In fact I am advised by the commission that some 37 cases—and 37 alone, not thousands—may be directly impacted upon by the decision of the High Court.

There are three issues which need to be addressed in response to the decision. Firstly, in terms of the enforcement proceedings, the government will be taking steps to immediately restore enforcement provisions in relation to the human rights commission. This will be done by amendments to a bill currently before the Senate dealing with the human rights commission and will see the reinstatement of the provisions which existed prior to the 1992 amendments.

The second issue concerns the longer term problems. Clearly the same issues which led to the enactment of the 1992 amendments are still real problems. I have asked a review team which is currently looking into the human rights commission to examine this matter. This team, which is currently comprised of the Department of Finance, my department and the commission, will be supplemented by Dr Sue Kenny, the president of the Administrative Review Council; Chris Sidoti, a commissioner of the Australian Law Reform Commission and John Basten, QC, a leading Sydney silk on human rights matters. The committee will consult widely, but I have asked for it to report back to me within a period of three months.

The final issue concerns those 37 cases where determinations have been made and where the High Court's decision has direct impact. It must be remembered that in all those cases it was open to respondents to take an appeal for a review to the Federal Court if they were unhappy with the determination of the human rights commission. It did not occur in all but I think one or two of those cases. We will not be refunding the money, but I have asked my department to work on a mechanism so that both respondents and complainants are placed as much as is practicable in the same position as they would have been if the amendments had not been enacted.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Can the minister inform the House of the reforms to the Commonwealth-state housing agreement agreed on by the housing ministers last Thursday?

—I thank the honourable member for Gilmore for his question. This year is the 50th anniversary of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement. Over five decades the Commonwealth-state housing agreement has been one of the foundations of social protection and care for those who are in most need. It is entirely appropriate that there should be genuine reform of the Commonwealth-state housing agreement, particularly in the area of public housing. In the 1950s, in the early years of the agreement, there was a matching of public housing with the great industrial estates of the manufacturing industry. In the current period, public housing is targeted towards those most in need, with almost 90 per cent of all new entrants into public housing being people dependent on pensions or benefits.

PARA.TAB: At the meeting of state housing ministers last week, there was an agreement that more public housing should be provided, particularly where jobs are. So there should be a refocusing of housing assistance through redevelopment of the older housing estates and revitalisation of those areas, together with additions to stock, particularly in areas where there are high levels of job availability but very low levels of public housing.

It was also agreed that state housing authorities should be much more focused on the management of tenants and on opening up more opportunities for choice on the part of tenants. Thirdly, states would be required under the new agreement to demonstrate that they are meeting national benchmarks, that these benchmarks should be published annually and the progress of the states in achieving under those benchmarks ought to be much more transparent.

As the Prime Minister said, during the 1980s we have delivered some of the great reforms in social security. Few countries in the world have a more cost efficient social security system than Australia has, or one that is better targeted to those most in need. In the 1990s, as in the 1940s, we delivered a great and historic white paper on employment which attunes labour market training programs to the very best in the world. No country has a more adequate approach to labour market reform than this country. We have to match social security reforms and the orientation of social security to labour market re-entry, labour market assistance—the wherewithal that enables someone to succeed—and ensure that people can be located where the jobs are and where the opportunities lie.

I simply conclude by saying this: against our record of and our commitment to reform I remind the House that when John Howard left the Treasury there was a massive cut in public housing. The Liberals went to the last election planning to cut $400 million off the public housing budget. Honourable members would be aware that the Institute of Public Affairs—which, in the 1940s, was the think tank for the Liberal Party, and still is—was advocating $500 million be taken off public housing.

I contrast our record of reform, and the level of commitment and agreement we have achieved with the states for reform, with the irresponsible, insensitive approach of the opposition typified by John Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, who, in his character, has shown no commitment at all to those who are most in need nor to ensuring that those who are most in need can be part of the mainstream of the Australian community. It is that continuing ideological commitment expressed in John Howard that contrasts with our record and the commitment we have to genuine and lasting reform.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Can the minister advise the House on the outcome of the dispute between the United States and China over the protection of intellectual property rights? What does this mean for Australia and the region?

—I thank the member for his question. The government welcomed the agreement, which was reported in the press recently, reached between China and the United States on a package that is designed to protect the intellectual property rights—a package described by the United States representative as the most comprehensive agreement on intellectual property rights ever negotiated.

PARA.TAB: The agreement will strengthen the enforcement of existing Chinese legislation against fraud, and it establishes a long-term plan for the protection of copyright, patents and trademarks. An effect of that is that it improves market access into China as a means of boosting the sale of genuine goods. The interests of both China and the United States have been served by this agreement. The United States has received guarantees on the protection of some of its fastest growing exports and, as far as China is concerned, its international reputation and ability to attract high level foreign investment have been enhanced.

The threat of a trade war, in which we might have seen punitive tariffs of 100 per cent imposed on a range of Chinese imports by the United States and a corresponding response from China, has been averted. That would have had the most serious consequences for regional trade as well as for direct US-China trade. The prospect of that has already unsettled Asian markets and caused particular concern in Hong Kong.

The honourable member asked about the importance of this for Australia. As the percentage of Australian exports of services and intellectual property rises, it becomes increasingly important to us that intellectual property rights are globally protected. The advice from our ambassador in Washington is that, other than for specific US-China joint ventures, that agreement will be implemented on a most favoured nation basis. That is important to us and we will be monitoring that aspect of the agreement.

The fact that this agreement could be reached in this very difficult area and at the last minute is a good sign that economic cooperation in the Asia-Pacific area is continuing to develop positively, including in APEC. Australia will be hosting for APEC members a seminar on intellectual property rights in Sydney in May as part of our efforts to promote the intellectual property outcomes from the Uruguay Round.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of any recent claims of increasing income inequality in Australia? Do these claims have any basis in fact? What impact does the tax transfer system have on the level of inequality?

—I thank the honourable member for Macquarie for her question. In recent times, the opposition has repeatedly tried to portray the situation in this country as being one of the most inequitable in the world. I have answered a number of questions in this place in which I have refuted those claims. In fact, the evidence is quite clear that it is the reverse of the case. Those definitive and authoritative studies that have taken all relevant factors into consideration, including earned incomes, transfer payments through the social security system, social wage elements such as Medicare, education training, child care, et cetera, have invariably refuted the claims of the opposition in this area. In fact, they show a very high level of relative equity in this country compared with other countries in the world.

PARA.TAB: In recent times, there has been throughout the developed world a trend for earned income differentials to increase. That phenomenon has not escaped Australia but all the evidence is that the impact of government policy on the outlays side and in terms of changes to the taxation system has been to mitigate and alleviate the underlying trend to greater earned income inequalities that permeates most developed countries.

If you look at the international statistics on earned income differentials—that is, even before you take into account the social wage and the transfer payment elements that we have talked about—the situation for this country relative to other countries looks pretty favourable. I refer honourable members to the OECD's Employment Outlook for July 1993 which contains a table on earnings dispersion for the year 1991. What that shows is that Australia has one of the least unequal distributions of earnings in the developed world, following the Scandinavian countries.

By way of contrast, the measure of inequality is shown to be 50 per cent higher in the UK than it is in this country and 2 1/2 times higher in the United States than it is in this country. What that reflects to a considerable extent is the evidence that the countries that have shown the strongest trend towards inequality have been those that have gone down the road of wholesale deregulation of labour markets and the stripping away of anything that we would understand as award protection. This is precisely the policy of the opposition, plus totally regressive changes in the tax system through the income splitting that the Leader of the Opposition has talked about and through cutting social wage expenditures. Every element of coalition policy would have the impact of making Australia a less equitable society.

So we are dealing with a case of sheer crocodile tears. The opposition obviously believes that by constant repetition of these claims it can gain some public acceptance. The reality is that the truth does not support the opposition. The objective evidence shows that this government, in its impact throughout its term, has had a major beneficial effect on equity in this society.
