TALK.START.PARA: —Last year the Higher Education Funding (Student Organisations) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (General Purposes) Bill were passed in this place taking money off states that passed legislation giving university students the choice of whether or not they joined their guild. The federal government did this despite those states having a mandate from the people to return choice to students.

PARA.TAB: This year, if any students exercise their right to choose not to join their student union, the federal government will give the equivalent of the fees lost to the guild, with that money being deducted from grants to states. So what we will have is less money for roads, hospitals, schools, police and so on while the guilds, which are more often than not politically aligned, will continue to thrive without the need to be accountable, representative or bipartisan.

I will refer the House to a number of examples which show that taxpayers' money is being wasted on these student guilds when it would be better spent on roads, hospitals, schools and police. The University of Western Australia guild in a recent edition of its newspaper carried an article—as a suggestion to earn money—advocating violence, befriending an old person to inherit their money, prostitution and selling body parts, to name but a few examples. Some people may suggest this is humour but, if so, it is pretty juvenile humour, and it is wrong if such trash is going to be published to expect the taxpayers to publish and finance it.

If the guilds want to publish this, they should do it with their own funds collected via the voluntary contributions of members who choose to join. That way students opposed to funding this rubbish can protest by withdrawing their membership. With compulsory membership they could not register such a protest. Now, even though the states have ensured choice to make guilds representative, the federal government has said to the guilds, `Don't worry, we will guarantee your funding, so now you can continue on your merry way of being unrepresentative and politically biased.'

There is also the Murdoch University guild's newspaper Metior, which is politically biased, full of juvenile humour—or what is expected to pass as juvenile humour—and does not provide any valuable information to students. Take its horoscope page. Here is a selection of quotes for some of the stars: `You will smut your best friend's sister's father's cousin which will cause the breakup of your friendship'; `Well rough me up with the exciting end of a cucumber'; `A month of major lubrication looks likely'; `You will not get a fornication in the foreseeable future.' The paper used a different `f' word, but I substituted `fornication' as a more parliamentary usable word with a similar meaning.

Anyhow, the horoscope goes on with other similar rubbish which some might consider humour but, even if it is, it is not worthier of funding than the states' essential services which are being deprived of funds to pay for this sort of nonsense. There is one more horoscope which I find most offensive, as would the colleague to whom it refers. Under the star sign of Leo, the author says, `I had sex with Carmen Lawrence and she was quite disappointing.' I do not think the honourable minister would lower herself to have anything to do with the author of this rubbish. Even if it is humour, it is offensive and denigrating to the minister.

Nevertheless, members opposite cannot complain because they voted last year to fund that trash ahead of roads, hospitals and other such services. The final publication, but certainly not the last piece of trash which members opposite voted last year to divert taxpayers' money to, is an Edith Cowan University booklet called Weird Sisters with an article entitled `The subversive politics of . . . ' I cannot give the entire title because it goes beyond the pale. The article talks about female genitalia and describes how women are taught to envy long brown legs, tight smooth arses and round lifted breasts, but were never informed of the ideal—and the House can work out the rest.

Members opposite think that all these activities are worthier of taxpayers' funds than education, roads, hospitals and police. When the government sits down for the budget to cut spending, the first place it could start is with the university guilds, which are ever so wasteful of taxpayers' money.

I would now like to turn my attention to an issue of concern to a group of constituents in my electorate known as WISE, Women's Implant Support Exchange. I was introduced to the complex social, medical and legal issues confronting recipients of breast implants over 18 months ago when I was approached by members of the Women's Implant Support Exchange, which is a consumer support group based in Western Australia.

Internal breast augmentation was considerably established in Australia with the use of silicone prosthesis in the 1960s. It is estimated that approximately 50,000 Australian women have had breast implants. The implants were used in reconstructing a new breast following mastectomy or for correcting breast abnormalities as well as for general breast augmentation.

While I do not understand why women took that course of action in the cases of augmentation, the issue here is that many of these women are now suffering disfigurement, injuries and medical problems. These women are suffering because, as recipients of breast implants, they were unprotected as a result of failures in regulating and reporting procedures which allowed these faulty products onto the Australian market in the first place. They were exploited by implant manufacturers who possessed knowledge that silicone implants were not safe but remained silent for years whilst they continued to market and sell their implants.

The implants from manufacturers mainly based in the United States were released untested onto the Australian market and were sold here for over 20 years. If regulation and reporting procedures had been effective, the problems associated with breast implants would have been discovered and thousands of women saved from disfigurement, injury and possible crippling disability. This has highlighted the need to regulate all future use of breast implants and implantable devices. Pre-market surveillance, the establishment of a consumer register and the provision of informed consent should be viewed as essential steps to be taken in the regulation of implantable devices. Additionally, mechanisms for an effective reporting scheme for device failure must be in place to prevent this sort of issue being repeated.

For over 20 years, Australian women believed, and indeed were told, that breast implants were safe and that they would last them a lifetime. Had the truth been revealed, these women would have been informed that the average lifespan of the older type implants is around 10 years, while the newer implants with the thinner wall lasts only four to seven years. What follows is that the porous outer shell eventually disintegrates, spilling silicone into the body, and it has been established that the silicone is linked to various health problems.

Australian and Canadian lawyers have been representing breast implanted women from their respective countries in the United States in a class action against the manufacturers of breast implants. Despite objections from those lawyers, the presiding judge in the proceedings approved a settlement which only permits women in countries other than the United States to share three per cent of the proposed $6 billion global settlement.

It is up to the Australian women to decide whether they wish to opt into the global settlement. There is no logical basis for the three per cent ceiling, and the US lawyers who negotiated this settlement have not acted in the interests of all women. Regrettably, the only available option at this stage is for Australian women to opt into the three per cent global settlement. Otherwise there is no recourse available to them.

Australian women are outraged and feel that this is the final blow in the chain of events which has caused thousands of them to be treated as worthless objects. The Canadian government has engaged lawyers in the United States aimed at assisting an appeal against the judge's decision and, in so doing, supporting the female citizens of its nation. I appeal to our government to look at assisting the women of Australia, who are facing a similar injustice, in whatever way it can.

Finally, I would like to mention a recent story on the 60 Minutes program on Channel 9. This story concerns a back surgeon in Western Australia, Dr Philip Hardcastle. Dr Hardcastle was the victim of a vicious story on 60 Minutes which was full of untruths, false allegations and personal smears against Dr Hardcastle in another example of the tall poppy syndrome. I am saying this not after speaking to Dr Hardcastle, but after being contacted by many patients who were disturbed at the gutter attempts by 60 Minutes to smear one of Australia's best back surgeons.

Members need only cast their minds back to the last Ashes test match between Australia and England to learn of the doctor's skill. Craig McDermott walked off one afternoon in terrible back pain; the next day, after being attended to by Dr Hardcastle, he wiped the floor with the Poms. Further proof of Dr Hardcastle's ability can be obtained from the likes of Bruce Reid, Bruce Yardley and Bob Simpson.

I understand that this hatchet job by 60 Minutes was prompted by an action group whose members were seeking compensation after having been injected with Depo-Medrol. They launched a smear campaign against Dr Hardcastle because he testified that the injuries to the members of that action group, who were seeking compensation, were blown out of all proportion. In return for him being honest, they set up a group with the sole intention of destroying Dr Hardcastle. Dr Hardcastle has been revolutionary in back surgery in Australia. He has recently introduced a new method known as the GRAF system. Because he told the truth about a few compensation claimants they set up a group with a vendetta to get him.

Having had Depo-Medrol injections myself, and knowing the pain that one incurs in the back, I can understand the desire of such people to have their problems fixed. Nevertheless, they have no right to dish up a story to 60 Minutes falsely trashing Dr Hardcastle. Similarly, 60 Minutes was totally unprofessional in its airing of the story. 60 Minutes edited the story with one intention: destroying Dr Hardcastle. The old adage `Do not let the truth get in the way of a good story' certainly came to the fore in this instance. Since the 60 Minutes story, Dr Hardcastle has unfairly lost business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance is with the New South Wales government and in particular the Road Traffic Authority. To be fair to the Road Traffic Authority, may I firstly pay it a compliment for the support it has given to the RTA New South Wales Big Bike Ride. By coincidence, the ride will be starting this Saturday and touring through my electorate for a period of 10 days. It will bring in about $1 million to the electorate. I would point out that it was my hard work which won that event for my area. The benefits that will be achieved by small business and the people of my area are attributable to my efforts. I very much appreciate the sponsorship of the RTA because it recognises that those with motorised vehicles are not the only users of the roads.

PARA.TAB: In turning to other matters, I wish to refer to the Minnamurra Bends. I apologised to this House for comments I made to a few local aldermen who considered that it was not correct to approach the RTA and give it curry for its lack of integrity in relation to road improvements in the Kiama area. Although this should be essentially a state and local government issue, I raise it in this House because within my files I have representations from people at the far south end of my electorate. The electorate of Gilmore extends from Kiama to a beautiful place called Depot Beach near North Durras which is within 10 kilometres of Batemans Bay.

The representations are from tourist operators and are along these lines: `Dear Mr Knott, can you do something about this Liberal state government in regard to the congestion on the roads at Kiama? It has been stated again and again by our clientele—whether they be motel accommodation seekers or caravan park seekers—that on any Sunday it takes at least two to three hours to cover five kilometres of road.' In itself, that may not seem to be a great problem, but we must understand that a large portion of my electorate owes its survival to the tourist trade and to the ancillary economic activity which is fostered by the tourist trade. A major deterrent to people coming to our area is of great concern to the whole of the electorate.

I live in the Kiama area, and I frequently take a bus up there to speak to people in the electorate. A man named John Wain suggested to me that I should organise a blockade on the Princes Highway adjacent to the Minnamurra Bends. Why has this come about? It has come about because the New South Wales state Liberal government under Mr Fahey will only put money into electorates held by Liberals or which are Liberal or National Party marginal electorates. Thus we have this great constriction on the economic development of the electorate of Gilmore. A previous speaker suggested that state governments should be spending their money on roads, hospitals, schools and police. I could not agree more.

However, under the 1990 heads of government agreement between the Commonwealth and the states the assumption was made that there would be equitable distribution of funds and that the premiers would not use the funds in a party political fashion. That has not been the case in my electorate. Our schools have been underfunded, our hospitals have closed and we have had no funding for our roads. The electorate of Bega adjoins my electorate. What has happened there? That electorate has more than enough dollars. It would be remiss of me not to sheet home the blame to those responsible. The New South Wales government is responsible for the shoddy and tawdry way in which it has administered the state.

The second issue I wish to raise is main road 92. Main road 92 is now a dirt road, but it has quite exceptional bridges. I am not noted for praising the wonderful administration of the Shoalhaven City Council, but in this case I must. The council had the foresight to put in bridge structures which would enable main road 92 to be functional if it was surfaced. I had a large number of representations on this matter and I approached the Premier of New South Wales. I expounded the benefits to tourism by linking us to Canberra, the benefits to manufacturing by linking us to Canberra and the benefits for incoming raw materials to producers and manufacturers in my area, but the Premier's comment was `Not in your lifetime, son.'

We look at the priorities for funding roads throughout New South Wales. One would have thought that something that had a massive amount of regional economic impetus behind it, which would lead to a regional area of New South Wales clawing ahead—it being one of the fastest growing residential areas in the state—would be embraced by the premier. Did he? No, he did not. He said, `Not in your lifetime, son.'

Unfortunately, on 25 March the people of New South Wales will work out whether they want high spending television ads telling us about beat police when they do not have any police at all in Bomaderry, where the rate of burglary is such that the local business people are up in arms. These are the sorts of things that the people of New South Wales will determine on 25 March. Unfortunately for Mr Fahey, he will come up short on schools, road funding and the numbers of police on the beat. We have seen the ads about beat police. If the government put the money it spent on these ads into the police, they would be better off.
But the final straw is hospitals. This man stood up and announced $600 million for new hospitals. Do you know what the reply of the people of New South Wales was?

TALK.START.PARA: —Great!

—They did not believe him. It was not `Great!' The reply was: `If you are so concerned about hospitals and health, why the hell haven't you done something over the last seven years? Why have you closed more hospitals than any other Premier in New South Wales history? Why have you withdrawn more services out of health than any other Premier in New South Wales history?' I can assure you that that was the day that Premier Fahey lost the right to be Premier of New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The real thing about this road funding is the absolute hypocrisy of these people. They turn and scream about not having enough funds, even though they were given all these funds in untied grants which they spent elsewhere on other things. But they have tried to put the burden of local roads further onto local councils and shed the burden of funding further onto local councils. This has to be one of the most outrageous actions of any government. The government gets more funding, tries to bleed it and then pushes the burden onto other areas, spending money on phoney ads, and trying to make the people who have to deal with the problems pay more. That is absolutely atrocious.

It would be good to see the RTA brought to account when Bob Carr gets into office, to be made a responsible organisation, looking after the safety and welfare of the people of New South Wales by providing them with an adequate road system which will not cause death, destruction and injury. I implore the people of New South Wales to take responsible action by voting out Mr Fahey and supporting their Labor candidates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the grievance debate this afternoon to highlight some of the inadequacies of the consultation process employed by the Queensland Labor government over the proposed electricity infrastructure to join Queensland with New South Wales through the national power grid.

PARA.TAB: The proposed infrastructure for Queensland has been termed Eastlink—a 330 kilovolt line, extending about 404 kilometres from Gatton, in the west of Brisbane, to Armidale. The proposed route of this preferred corridor was announced by the Queensland energy minister, Mr McGrady, a few weeks ago. While, as I have said, it is part of a plan to bring Queensland into a national power grid, in effect, it is not a national power grid. The grid will link Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia together, but it certainly does not link with Tasmania, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Perhaps for very good practical reasons, they will not be part of it. So it is wrong to call it a national power grid.

The consultation process, Queensland Labor government style, really has to be seen to be believed. Before the task force was appointed, before any consultation took place in reference to the Eastlink proposal, and before any of the general public was advised, the Queensland Labor government went ahead and acquired some land specifically for the purpose of the Eastlink proposal. Of course, we have become used to this sort of tactic with the Labor Party in Queensland. It is part of the old union style: `If you don't like me I'll still walk over the top of you.' Of course, the Queensland Labor government has been trying to portray itself as a caring government but I can assure this parliament that with this Eastlink proposal the people will not be walked over by the Queensland Goss government.

The minister responsible, Mr McGrady, announced seven months ago that a consultation process in relation to Eastlink was to take place. What has happened since? He got the Queensland Electricity Commission to put up 25 public displays. This whole project is going to cost something like $400 million and will be 404 kilometres long. There have been 13 public meetings. That is the consultation process adopted by Minister McGrady in Queensland.

After seven months, after 13 public meetings, after 25 public displays in towns along or near the route, the minister announced the preferred corridor. If the minister had been truly consulting with the people and was really concerned about the comments of many local members and the community in general—which is the most important thing—he would have been at the meeting I was at last week in Allora.

Allora is a little town on the southern Darling Downs, a very pretty country town of about 1,000 inhabitants. Eight hundred people turned up at a public meeting there last Wednesday night. Allora is about one hour and 40 minutes drive from Brisbane, where the minister was. Surely, if he was concerned for the residents of Allora, and for the other people along the corridor just west of the Great Dividing Range, the minister would have attended.

He could have driven the one hour and 40 minutes to Allora and attended the meeting. He would have had a driver to drive him there so it would not have required a great deal of effort. It would have been just a matter of taking a little bit of time out and talking to the people. But not this minister; he is committed to the line. He was committed even before the proposition was put to the people. That is evidenced by the fact that the Queensland government had already bought some land for this Eastlink proposal.

Minister McGrady seems determined to go ahead with this proposal, despite what the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology said in its report of 1992. Chapter 9 of that report recommended that Queensland not be included in the initial assessment of possible grid extensions until the state demonstrated that its inclusion was economically achievable. It said that the Queensland state government, as at that time, had been unable to provide such economic information to either the Queensland public or the Queensland Electricity Commission. So much for the minister doing his job.

The people of Allora say that this is war. They are very concerned that only 12 months ago, and against their wishes, their local authority was amalgamated with the city of Warwick. That was the state government consulting with the people of Allora shire less than 12 months ago. In a local referendum, 900 people of the 1,000 residents of the town of Allora voted against an amalgamation of the two shires. In fact, the minister responsible, the minister for local government in Queensland, Mr Mackenroth, went further and put two extra shires into that amalgamation, notwithstanding overwhelming opposition from the community.

Last week the people of Allora expressed a lot of concern about being unable to prevent the minister from going ahead with the Eastlink proposal. The only way that the people of Allora are going to be happy is if they see a change of government in Queensland before the end of this year. The Leader of the Opposition in Queensland, Rob Borbidge, said at a meeting only two days prior to the Allora meeting that under a coalition government in Queensland there will be no Eastlink and that any land acquired by the state government would be given back to the people at no cost to those people. Because of the failure of the minister to consult with them and listen to their concerns, the only way the people of Allora can proceed now to stop the proposal—apart from sitting in front of the bulldozers—is to change the government in Queensland.

I want to put on the public record some of the concerns which were expressed at the meeting at Allora last Wednesday. People are concerned about the power line that will cut across the southern Darling Downs including towers 40 to 45 metres in height, with seven wires strung across the productive Darling Downs. They are concerned about the effect it will have on the $77 million rural tourism industry in that part of Queensland and the concern is growing daily.

Many farmers on the southern Darling Downs are now taking on farm hosting as part of their overall operation and part of a diversity to agricultural income on their farms. But the minister has not listened. The people are concerned about the effects on agricultural production on the Darling Downs. Let us look at where the Darling Downs is. It could well be the food bowl that services and provides food to the growing Asian market. It is less than seven hours flying time from Brisbane. It is an important agricultural area with some of the finest agricultural land in this country.

What is the Goss Labor government doing in Queensland? He is not listening to the people. He has never listened to the people. He was committed to the whole project before any announcement was made on the preferred corridor or even the fact that there would be a Queensland linking with the southern states. These people have other concerns, but time prevents me from going into those concerns in detail this afternoon.

Why has the Queensland government not upgraded the infrastructure needs for Queensland's sake? Queensland has some of the cheapest and the most efficient coal in Australia. It is environmentally friendlier than many other coal sources in Australia. Why has the Labor government not done as previous governments have done: upgraded the infrastructure, produced the power and created jobs for Queenslanders? They are the questions that the people of Allora and people along the southern Darling Downs want answered by the minister. But the minister, when he could have been at the meeting last week, was in Brisbane stuck up in his little burrow. He failed to come out to confront the 800 people who quite clearly have many grievances they want aired and answered. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We live in an era when significant progress has been made in Australia in assisting many groups of disadvantaged people within our community. The Federal Labor government can take a degree of pride in many achievements in those areas—for example, in assisting people with disabilities. There is one substantial group, however, which is going backwards fairly rapidly because of the actions of state governments: injured workers. I would like to talk today about workers compensation and the need for the federal government to become more directly and actively involved in ensuring that injured workers get proper compensation, proper rehabilitation and true justice which has been, and is increasingly being, denied to them.

PARA.TAB: If we look across the country, we see a varied picture. There are different problems in different states, but no state has a really good workers compensation system. In Victoria, unless you are extremely seriously injured, you are thrown off benefits after two years and onto social security thereby shifting the cost of the problem from employers and employer premiums to the Commonwealth. In Queensland, if you do not have access to common law and are unable to prove negligence, you are in a position where you have a maximum benefit of $72,000. If you suffer an injury at a relatively early age that makes you unable to work long term, the maximum compensation you can get is $72,000. It is roughly similar to the old Victorian system prior to Workcare.

Comcare, which is probably better than most systems—certainly with respect to benefits—has an appalling structure on procedures. It is a very common experience for people with Comcare to go through all sorts of hoops and dramas to get hold of somebody who can make a decision about their situation. Whichever part of the country we look at, workers have problems.

Lack of uniformity in itself is a serious problem, something which many major employers agree with. There is a lowest common denominator effect already occurring across the states where different state governments, in order to attract industry to their particular state, decide that one of the ways they can do that is by reducing compensation premiums. How will that be done? By reducing benefits.

Lack of uniformity creates a serious problem for many major employers. In some circumstances, employers have to doubly insure the one worker, because that worker might perform work in two states—for example, interstate driving duties. On virtually every major indicator in workers compensation structures, whether it be definitions, benefits, journey accidents, the common law process or appeals, there is no uniformity across the states.

In Victoria, the state government has added insult to injury by spending $8 million on Workcover ads designed to show a totally unreal picture of the compensation reality. They show friendly, loving doctors who are all very keen to help the poor injured worker; employers with nice, friendly faces who are desperate to help them get well. There are cliches about the types of injury—the broken arm and stuff like that—totally ignoring the reality.

Late last year I wrote a column in the Herald-Sun about these ads—the impact that they have on people and the injustices in the new system in Victoria. My office and I have been deluged with calls and letters from people who have had serious injuries. I have had people crying on the phone. People have spoken about the demoralising impact of these advertisements, how they have conveyed an image that is totally out of step with reality and have helped to compound all of the problems that people with workplace injuries suffer in the community, on top of the most obvious problems.

In my view, the general thrust of the recent Industry Commission report on workers compensation was good. It had some weaknesses, but the basic thrust, which is something that we do not expect from the Industry Commission, was very important and is something that members of the opposition should take note of: employers in this country do not bear enough of the costs of workplace injuries and, therefore, that imposes a competitive disadvantage on good employers. Bad employers with unsafe workplaces are getting away with less of a cost and on purely economic rationalist grounds they should be bearing the full cost of their poor practices.

Existing regulatory structures in health and safety are grossly inadequate. Companies that kill people get piddling fines. Even when they get a substantial fine, such as in the recent Nadenbousch case in Victoria where the fine of $120,000 for manslaughter was imposed, the same principals were back trading under a different name fairly shortly thereafter.

If someone in the community negligently drives a car and kills somebody, he or she is liable to end up in gaol. If an employer negligently runs his workplace and kills somebody, he is liable to end up with a $1,000 fine. The injustice of that is absolutely patent.

In 1974-75, the Whitlam government endeavoured to introduce a national compensation scheme which was designed, like the New Zealand scheme, not only to provide universal cover with various divisions but also to cover people for accidents and injuries both in the work force and outside and to be based on no fault. The issues are very much the same as now. We still have fragmented state schemes with many injustices, inadequate benefits, excessive administration costs and all of the problems that I have referred to before.

Although I accept that the political reality is such that the Woodhouse model, as it has been termed, is unlikely to be introduced in Australia, at least in the foreseeable future—if for no other reason than some of the key players, including key unions, are not very keen on it—I would like to state here today that I am a supporter of that model and I will continue to work within the processes of the parliament and my party to advance that concept. I believe ultimately that is the way we will have to go in order to get justice for injured workers and people injured in the broader community and to ensure that the administrative costs and inefficiencies are kept to a minimum in the system.

The problem we now face is that if we do not act the states are going to introduce uniformity, but uniformity based on the lowest common denominator—what they want to achieve in terms of lowest premiums and with minimal consideration for the interests of injured workers.

We have heard many times in this debate about fraud and bludgers and all the myths, which are gross distortions of the reality of workers compensation and life for injured workers. The reality for injured workers is a loss of job, a loss of future employability—they are often rejected by an employer who has previously been very friendly towards them—pain, marriage break-ups, serious financial problems, psychological problems, a loss of confidence and a loss of self-esteem. We even have situations where workers incur injuries that people deny even exist.

Those who whinge about the cost that workers compensation imposes on the community should keep in mind the reality that the actual cost of workers compensation premiums across the states varies between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 per cent of total wage costs. If we put that in the context of things such as some of the grossly excessive pay hikes that senior executives have been taking in the past 10 years, we start to get a sense of the real injustice we are putting on injured workers. We are saying that it is fine for people to be paid $1 million or $2 million to run a company—far more than has been the case in the past—yet we are not going to allow somebody who has been seriously injured in the work force to live with dignity and some degree of financial security because his ability to earn a wage has been taken away from him through no fault of his own.

In conclusion, I will read a letter which is one of the many responses I received to a column I wrote in the paper. It is not my usual practice to do this. Some members on the other side seem to find reading a letter from a constituent the only basis on which they can make a speech. I hope their constituents keep writing to them, otherwise they will not have anything to say. I think this letter illustrates very well the sorts of problems that genuine, very seriously injured workers face. This letter comes from a woman who has been a teacher for a long time and who has had a spinal fusion and a laminectomy—serious back operations; no bludging, no malingering. The letter says:

Since the injury my lifestyle has changed dramatically. I have undergone two major operations. I have lost thousands of dollars in pay and superannuation. I am left with a permanent disability, which I see as serious. I no longer wear high heels, go dancing, do the garden, or walk long distances with my grandchildren. My husband does the heavier household chores and shopping. I cannot assist my aged parents with their household chores. I have not gone to the theatre since the fusion, for I cannot sit for any length of time. I limit my social activities and have curtailed my community activities.

I now live a restricted lifestyle and suffer pain every day of my life. I have no hope of a happy, financially secure and healthy retirement. I have lost friends who have openly told me they resented "their" taxes paying for my WorkCover payments and medical expenses, thanks to those ads. I have argued, to no avail, that after working for 43 years perhaps they are my own taxes anyway.

My own doctors say it is unreasonable to expect me to return to normal full-time teaching. The WorkCover doctors are adamant that my permanent injury is "minor", and are well practised in writing reports in such a way as to influence decisions to go against the injured worker. I am allowed no legal representative, and have really no idea what to present on my own behalf.

I am incensed WorkCover even suggests I can work full time as a primary school teacher, after having undergone a laminectomy and spinal fusion. I am also incensed that instead of compassion and common sense I should be forced to seek conciliation to prove my pain and injury.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reality of life for injured workers in our society. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in this grievance debate, I grieve, once again, for the state of our nation. This is the 50th anniversary since the end of the Second World War. Australia has embarked on a program called Australia Remembers. I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) on the amount of work he has put into this program. It is correct that we should look back to those events of 1940 to 1945 and that we should commemorate and remember those who sacrificed so much for the freedom and prosperity that Australia has enjoyed in the ensuing years.

PARA.TAB: I cannot help observing that Australia today is very different from the Australia of 50 years ago. Those who made those sacrifices 50 years ago must despair in many cases at what they see happening around them in Australia today. Indeed, many of the veterans in my electorate—and I have a large number of them who speak to me—do tell me just that. Some of them have put it very succinctly by saying that they wonder now whether it was worth what they did 50 years ago.

On the economic side, since 1983, under this Labor government, we have seen our national debt increase sevenfold. We have seen unemployment increase from 300,000 to 900,000. Regrettably, the rate of youth unemployment is about three times that of the rate of adult unemployment. We have seen our current account deficit continue to escalate. We have seen the extent of foreign ownership in this country—as this government rushes to sell off the family jewels, as it were—escalating and threatening to turn our children into peasants. We have the prospect of increased taxes once again and we see interest rates increasing. Now people are frightened of the prospect of yet another bust after the very short amount of relief we had after the worst recession in 60 years.

Of greatest concern is the extent of welfare, which has become endemic in our society. It obviously has to be paid for and, as far as this government is concerned, it has to be paid for out of increased taxes. The government is already softening up the electorate for its budget. It keeps trotting out the old welfare line that we are, in fact, a low tax country. But in 1967, 12 per cent of household income went on taxes. In 1990 that figure had risen to 17.7 per cent. In 1967 the median taxpayer paying the median tax rate paid 24.6 per cent. In 1990 that figure had risen to 40.3 per cent. So much for the misconception that is often put before us—that Australia is a low tax nation.

The fact is that we pay high taxes—some people pay disproportionately high taxes—because of the number of programs this government keeps coming up with to try to solve the problems it created in the first place. Hardly a day goes by that we do not hear a minister coming in here to announce a new program that is going to cost so many millions of dollars. We get tired of it, particularly as they are trying to solve problems that they created in the first place.

Welfare creates dependency. Dependency undermines self-reliance and personal responsibility. Something is wrong when the system actually allows people to be better off from not working. That is the effect of many of these so-called programs that have been introduced by this government. Despite some of their efforts to redress that, they have not been at all successful.

The problem for the unemployed—the 800,000 or so, which is underestimated by an enormous amount—is not, by and large, an unwillingness to work. It is a lack of real jobs. Despite the assurances we received from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in question time today, which were met by derisive cries from this side of the House, the government's record on job creation is not all it is cracked up to be. Most of the jobs it tells us it has created are part-time jobs or short hour jobs and are not real, full-time, solid jobs that are going to last.

The greatest concern that is expressed to me by veterans in the community—those who served 50 years ago to make Australia what it ought to be today—is the social degradation which has occurred in our country. It was interesting to hear the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in the parliament today, in answer to a dorothy dix question, expressing concern about the increase we are seeing in the number of teenagers and young people taking up smoking. This is the same health minister who recently funded a so-called safe sex guide which was published in Cleo magazine. This safe sex guide clearly, openly and graphically promotes sodomy. The sex guide does not warn young people about the health risks of sodomy. It does not tell them not to do it. It goes to great lengths to tell them how to do it.

I do not think you have to be a doctor—and I have certainly sought doctors' advice about this—to realise that sodomy has been largely responsible for the spread of AIDS. That is why it spread so rapidly amongst the homosexual community originally. That is why it is now being spread in the heterosexual community. The minister, I believe, needs to answer questions about the government's sponsorship of this particular safe sex guide. The publication which appeared in Cleo clearly has her endorsement. She says in the article:

SPEECH.PARA: In an effort to further inform young women and men about STDs and HIV-AIDS, the federal government has collaborated with Cleo to produce this safe sex booklet. It deals with sexual health in a factual and non-judgemental way and is a resource that everyone should read.

I think most people in Australia would totally disagree that it is a resource that everyone should read. In fact, most decent Australians—I suggest the vast majority of Australians—would be very concerned if their teenage daughters were reading this magazine, particularly the government-sponsored insert. I suspect that if she does not endorse the guide she has perpetrated a worse crime, a crime almost of Kellyesque proportions, by endorsing something she has not read. The question is whether $250,000 of taxpayers' money has been spent on something the contents of which the health minister is only vaguely aware of or did she read only the cover and not the contents? I happen to believe that these questions—and I am looking forward to receiving the answers—very much need to be asked. They are questions that are being asked by a lot of people who have become aware of this out there in Australia at the moment.

I want to pay tribute to a Queensland journalist by the name of Laurie Cavanagh. He has been raising this matter consistently. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to rise in the grievance debate today on a matter of concern not only to me but to my constituents. It is something they have had to put up with for a great deal of time. In recent months—and this is what brought it to my attention again—we have heard much said about airports and airport noises in Sydney. We have even seen protests. We have seen petitions and complaints from both sides of politics, and we have seen huge media coverage of the event.

PARA.TAB: But there are residents within my electorate who for several years have been putting up with extreme levels of road noise. I am referring to my constituents who are residents along the Cumberland Highway and who have had many sleepless nights since that highway was completed through that section of my electorate in the early 1990s. By way of background for honourable members, the construction of the Cumberland Highway was a major improvement to infrastructure in south-western Sydney and turned roads in my electorate such as Warren Road, Betts Road, Jersey Road, Smithfield Road and Palmerston Road into major thoroughfares.

The section of the Cumberland Highway within my electorate has been identified as being exposed to relatively high levels of traffic noise. In fact, a very small primary school, St Gertrude's, which is located on the Cumberland Highway at Smithfield, recently decided that it needed to add new classrooms on its site. In order to have a development application approved by the Fairfield City Council, the school had to construct a noise abatement fence around that section of the new classrooms at a cost, I might add, of some $9,000. So a local school, providing a community service, had to spend $9,000 to protect just one small section of the school. The students who are not in that section of the school still have to cope with high levels of traffic noise. If an appropriate fence was constructed around their section, it would cost another $27,000.

I suppose honourable members may ask why I am bringing up something like this and what relevance it has to the federal government. The fact is that the federal government supplies funding to the New South Wales government to alleviate traffic noise for residents. But the Fahey government in New South Wales has had its own agenda. It has formulated guidelines which ensure that roads in Liberal state electorates have a greater chance of receiving funding. The policy of the New South Wales state government requires noise attenuation for projects undertaken since 1988. When I first investigated this matter I thought that naturally I would be able to have restoration for properties within my electorate. But this law came into effect in 1988, the year the Greiner Liberal-National Party government came into office.

The Liberal government has now shamelessly favoured its own electorates in the building of roads since 1988. It is these roads which now receive noise attenuation. Thus, for example, properties along Pennant Hills Road, the region of Beecroft and Thompson's Corner, have received that noise attenuation treatment. Anyone can drive through that area and see what I am talking about. It is part of the Cumberland road system and traffic on that Pennant Hills Road section largely flows into my electorate and through my electorate along that Cumberland Highway. The residents of Beecroft—I do not begrudge it to them—have received, at no cost to them, well constructed 1.8 metre fences built in brick chosen by the residents and accompanied by beautiful polished wooden gates. The residents of my electorate have received nothing.

Never in my time in politics have I seen a more shameful diversion of Commonwealth funds for the political ends of a state government. Some $7.2 million has been spent of federal government funding on noise attenuation on the Pennant Hills Road section of the Cumberland Highway. Nothing has been spent on noise abatement on the same road that goes through Greystanes, Woodpark, Smithfield or Fairfield West. There is no state government policy dealing with noise alleviation on roads, the Cumberland Highway in particular, that have been constructed before 1988 and that have continued to be built after that period.

However, I understand, following the repeated representations that I have made, that the Sydney region of the Roads and Traffic Authority is currently undertaking an assessment of RTA roads in the metropolitan areas. It will be re-evaluating its policies in this regard after that assessment. It makes unquestionable good sense to have a policy dealing with traffic noise on roads that are now major highways. The only possible explanation for not having such a policy must be the political agenda of the present state Liberal coalition government.

I have spoken in this House before about the need for cooperation between state and federal governments. It is the concept which underpins the constitution. I have attacked the Fahey Liberal-National government for not cooperating with federal authorities on the issues of youth homelessness, supported accommodation assistance and the provision of child care. The Fahey government has established a reputation for unmitigated obstructionism in derailing federal government initiatives.

As the federal member representing the residents of Prospect, I am furious that federal funds which are designed to be allocated to those in need of relief from traffic noise, regardless of the way in which they vote, have been diverted almost exclusively to residents in Liberal electorates. This has got to change. I believe that on 25 March the voters will no longer be fooled and will certainly be casting their votes to make sure that this, and other initiatives which I have raised in this House and that have been the fault of the Liberal-National Fahey government, will change.

I commend this decision to future governments. When we talk about roads, noise alleviation and work that needs to be done we must make sure that for roads such as the Cumberland Highway that are given a directory of significance and a direction, going through a number of electorates, that what is applicable for one electorate in noise attenuation must be applicable in all electorates. That is why I grieve today on behalf of the constituents I represent within the Prospect electorate who have at no time been offered courtesy or even part of the $7.2 million that this federal Labor government has allocated to the state to make sure some work is done and some attention is paid to those areas of responsibility under the state Liberal government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some brief comments while we are discussing the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994 as a whole and just restate the coalition's position on this legislation. PARA.TAB: I will share with the House something that was raised with me only 48 hours ago, and that is the case of companies who have negotiated an enterprise agreement and they are funding the costs directly of their employees. If this legislation is passed in its present form, that will mean that those enterprise agreements will collapse.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the shadow minister, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), has said, we have some grave concerns with the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill 1994. They were outlined in my speech during the second reading debate when I moved a second reading amendment which clearly set out the matters of principle which are of concern to the opposition and, indeed, to many people abroad in the community.

PARA.TAB: I said, and have always said, that our concern is not to give power to the health funds and allow them to become rich and powerful—as the minister seems to want them to become—but to give fairness to the individuals who from time to time need health care in the hospital system. That has always been our overriding concern. The system is not fair.

I have read all sorts of comments in the media that the minister is going to agree to the default payment system. There is an opportunity here and now for the minister to put it on the record. Are the press reports true? Does the minister intend to agree to a system of default payments which are meaningful so that private hospitals which are presently able to exist and carry out a service to the public can continue to do so? That is the question we want answered.

In my speech in the second reading debate I said that without this legislation there is currently nothing to prevent health funds entering into negotiations with private hospitals and having a preferred provider agreement covering all out-of-pocket expenses. At the moment there is nothing to stop them doing that and, indeed, they could have been doing it for some considerable time. As I pointed out earlier in the debate, that is precisely what has happened in Victoria. In Victoria, the agreements were entered into, health insurance premiums went up and more people left private health insurance.

The second question I put to the minister is one I foreshadowed earlier. In August 1994, the minister stated that these reforms would make the cost of health insurance premiums come down and, therefore, people would stop leaving health insurance funds. The minister set out this plan in August 1994 and private health insurance membership has continued to decline. It has gone down again, with membership now at 36.3 per cent. At the time I asked whether this reform would cause the minister to take out private health insurance—because she can afford it—or whether it would force out ordinary mums and dads, who will no longer be able to choose a doctor or hospital. We also drew attention to other issues. We said that, if the minister had agreed to the principles, we would have agreed to the second reading. Not only has that been taken as being inevitable but also submissions are already being sought for a hearing of that committee before the legislation has even passed from the House into the Senate. That is not exactly a normal or proper agreement but one that acknowledges the reality that this inquiry is needed.

There are two questions at this stage. Firstly, is the minister going to take out private health insurance so that next time she needs to slip between the sheets in a private hospital she will be able to do so, knowing that she is not sponging off the mums and dads who keep those beds open? Secondly, is the minister going to agree to the default payment in respect of hospitals which are left out of preferred provider agreements—as is the situation now and as would be provided for in our foreshadowed amendments—or not? Are the press reports correct or are they misleading? What was the source of those reports?

This legislation is unashamedly designed to help consumers—not private hospitals, doctors or private health insurance funds, but consumers. As the responsible minister, I want to make it very clear that I am delighted with the opposition we are getting from the private hospitals and the doctors. SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments of the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Most of the amendments have already been introduced as customs tariff proposals.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 1 contains amendments announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the 1994-95 federal budget and have operated since 11 May 1994. The amendments give effect to the government's decision to decrease the customs duty on topped crude oil by 2.977c per litre and on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 1.977c per litre. These changes will lower input costs for industry and will specifically benefit coastal shipping, export oriented mineral projects and certain manufacturing operations.

Schedule 2 will operate from 1 July 1994. In May 1993, this government decided to reduce the coverage of the Australian system of tariff preferences from 1 July 1993 by phasing out the most developed countries from access to the developing country margin of preference for certain imported commodities. On 4 May this year my colleague Senator Cook announced in the Working Nation white paper that a similar phase-out would be extended to the remainder of commodities in the customs tariff with the exception of cheese, sugar, unmanufactured tobacco and certain replacement components for passenger motor vehicles. The phase-out of the margin of preference will be achieved by freezing the developing country rate for the subject commodities at the pre-1 July 1994 level.

The Treasurer also announced on budget night an increase of 1.194c per litre in customs duties on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene for use in aircraft. This increase is a further part of the process announced by the government in the 1992-93 federal budget of a phased introduction of full recovery of the costs incurred by the Civil Aviation Authority in implementing aviation safety standards and 50 per cent of the costs of safety standards setting and compliance by the Civil Aviation Authority.
The rate of duty on aviation gasoline is subject to further variation in respect of the duty collected and paid to the CAA to recover airways costs attributable to aviation gasoline powered aircraft.

The reduction of 7.521c per litre follows the adoption by the CAA of a marginal cost basis for the pricing of services provided to operators of gasoline powered aircraft. This approach has been adopted in recognition of the fact that a large proportion of CAA facilities are put in place because they are required for regular public transport operations mostly undertaken by aviation kerosene powered aircraft.

As part of the government's policy pertaining to the automotive industry until the year 2000, tariffs on passenger motor vehicle—PMV—replacement components were to be maintained at 15 per cent from 1 July 1992. Amendments contained in this schedule redress certain anomalies which arose in the implementation of the government's policy. Specifically, a number of tariff classifications were omitted from the original PMV schedule of replacement components. There was also a small number of other classifications for which rates of duty had already fallen below the 15 per cent threshold.

These amendments introduce a consistent application of government assistance for imported replacement components for the Australian automotive sector. The Malaysia-Australia trade agreement provides bilateral trade concessions for signatory countries. The amendments contained in this schedule provide a free rate of duty for unvulcanised compounded rubber from Malaysia.

Schedule 3 will operate from 23 September 1994. Following a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 19 January 1994, the government's intended assistance rate of 12 per cent—now 10 per cent—for semi-finished lens blanks for spectacles was reduced to free.

The government has put in place a regimented decrease in tariff protection since July 1988. The purpose of this amendment is to restore the previous level of assistance for semi-finished lens blanks and a structured phase-down for the subject goods.

This bill also contains a number of other minor technical or administrative amendments. Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is a relatively uncontroversial bill that would enact a series of minor modifications to the Customs Tariff Act. The sections of the bill relating to petroleum duty, aviation gasoline and kerosene are identical to the comparable sections of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994.

PARA.TAB: Tariff modifications in excise bills apply only to domestically produced goods—in this case certain petroleum products. The customs amendments in this bill are needed to cover the importation of those products. Most of the amendments in the bill were originally introduced as customs tariff proposals.

With regard to petroleum duty, the bill proposes to reduce the customs duty on topped crude oil by 2.977c per litre and the duty on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 1.977c per litre. The reductions were announced in the 1994-95 budget and took effect on 11 May 1994. The reductions partially offset the 3c per litre petroleum duty increase that was announced in the 1993-94 budget. The government wanted to increase the duty by another 2c per litre, but it abandoned that plan in October 1993.

The government has now conceded that even the 3c per litre increase had a significantly adverse effect on import costs in the mining and shipping industries. It is typical of this arrogant and out of touch government that it took it a year to understand these effects of the duty increase. The consequences were apparent to everybody else throughout Australia on budget day 1993. As we have informed the House previously, the cost increases to coastal shipping were such that they defeated all of the gains that had been achieved through the rationalisation of crewing and all those other benefits. They were wiped out in one fell swoop.

The production costs also of a major user of fuel oil in the mining industry, Nabalco, increased by $9 per tonne by this measure. The increase effectively imposed a 13 per cent levy on its alumina exports. The duty increase wiped out the benefits of the final stage of the shipping industry reform program, which I have mentioned already. The following day the Treasurer announced a 5c per litre increase in duty, having just signed the previous agreement. We tried to explain to the government the effects of the duty increase. The government's response at that time, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Snow, may remember, was to guillotine the debate on the bill.

So we welcome the government's decision to reduce the duty on these petroleum products. It is disappointing that it has not reviewed the duty increase applying to the road transport and rail industries as well. I am just wondering when the government, having so narrowed its tax options after the last election, is ever going to wake up to the debilitating effects on our transport sector of taxing fuel at ever increasing rates. Australia is not a tiny place. Its major resources are diversified throughout the country and can be found thousands of miles from the sea. Yet we continue to put massive taxes on transport in the form of fuel levies, sales taxes and other duties on road equipment and rail equipment. It is just so silly that the Brazilians can put orange juice into this country without practically any tax, including a tariff, yet our Australian producers are paying $1000 or $2000 a week in tax on every semitrailer carting their product to the equivalent markets. It is an unbelievable situation that has been allowed to develop.

Parts of this bill also deal with developing country preferences. On 20 February 1993 the Prime Minister announced that the government planned to modify the tariff preference arrangements applying to the more advanced developing countries such as Thailand, Vietnam and the Philippines. The government accordingly phased out the preferential tariffs applying to imports of chemicals, textiles, clothing and footwear, rubber and leather goods, dried fruit, and fruit juice.

In Working Nation the government announced that it intended to extend the phase out even further. Accordingly, the bill proposes to extend it to cover all those countries' exports to Australia except cheese, unmanufactured tobacco, sugar, and replacement components for passenger motor vehicles. The list of states that will still be entitled to receive tariff concessions is short and includes the most poverty stricken countries on earth, such as Bhutan, Haiti and Somalia. The bill also extends the Malaysia-Australia trade agreement to cover unvulcanised compounded rubber.

With regards to aviation gasoline and kerosene, the bill proposes to increase the air safety regulation duty on avgas and avtur by 1.194c per litre. It also seeks to enact a 7.521c per litre decrease in the component of avgas excise associated with the CAA's airways services. The net change in duty on avgas is therefore a decrease of 6.327c per litre. Avgas is the fuel used in piston driven propeller aircraft. Avtur is used in jet aircraft and turbine powered propeller aircraft.

The tariff variations in the bill took effect from 1 July 1994 and were first announced in the 1994-95 budget. The air safety regulation duty has its origins in the government's aviation safety cost recovery program, which progressed fitfully through the 1980s. After several false starts, and after incurring the intense distrust of most of the industry, the government announced in the 1992-93 budget that the cost of setting and enforcing safety standards would be shared between the industry and the government, with the government meeting 50 per cent of the cost up to a limit of $22.8 million, indexed.

In 1993 the government increased the duty on avgas by 0.264c per litre and introduced an 0.264c per litre excise on avtur as an interim cost recovery measure. The increases took effect on 1 September 1993. The increase in the avgas duty was more than offset by a 3.013c per litre decrease in the duty that took effect from 1 July 1993. The 1.194c per litre increase in the duty on avgas and avtur is a further step in that cost recovery program. The 7.521c per litre decrease in the avgas duty is attributable to a reduction in the cost of providing airways services such as air traffic control and flight information. Airways services are funded by charges on avtur aircraft and by a portion of the avgas excise. Over the last few years the CAA has substantially reduced its expenditure on delivery of those services by consolidating its operations. The reduction in the duty on avgas passes some of those savings onto the general aviation sector, which largely uses avgas powered aircraft. Avtur operators have already received significant benefits from the authority's cost reduction program; the CAA reduced its airways charges by $90 million in 1992-93 and by $109 million in 1993-94. This is a positive move and one the opposition supports simply because, as we have said so many times and as I have just said, all the transport costs on road and rail flow through to the eventual and final providers, be they tourist operators or whatever. Such reductions will make Australia a more competitive international destination, which it has failed to be on its domestic routes.

In Building a Competitive Australia it was announced that the tariffs on replacement passenger motor vehicle components would be frozen at 15 per cent once they had reached that level on 1 July 1992. It is an interesting thing to be reminded in the context of some of today's efforts that this government actually brought down a program called Building a Competitive Australia. Of course, this government's view of expenditure cutting is that the state governments should cut expenditure and the Commonwealth should spend more on its own purpose outlays. The Prime Minister stands up here, sticks his chest out and says, `I have reduced expenditures as a percentage of GDP.' He does not go back to find out by how much the states have had to increase their taxes, particularly through levies on services such as electricity supply, et cetera, to make up the difference. Of course, the whole public sector revenue requirement is consequently going through the roof.

We have read the reference to Building a Competitive Australia. But, while all that has been happening, the government has three authorities that should be to the forefront in this competition policy. The government is trying to sell Qantas. To maximise the sale return, it drove a competitor out of the country. It had told Air New Zealand that it could come along. But, all of a sudden, when it looked as though it might affect the price of Qantas, the government said, `We don't want competition with Qantas. We want competition with the electricity authorities of the states.'

We go a step further and read in today's papers that the government is now almost committed to bulking up its international airports state by state and selling them to one buyer. In other words, Kingsford-Smith and Badgerys Creek go to the same developer. I can tell you that Badgerys Creek will not go ahead too quickly. Quite clearly, if you have no competition, Badgerys Creek will be travelling very slowly because no commercial operator is going to spend money in competition with his own investment.

It makes an absolute and unmitigated mockery of a competition policy if you are going to have two major international airports and let one bloke run both of them when one has not been built yet. It would be different if they were both operating and the operator said, `Okay.' But, when one is not built yet, what incentive exists to get it up and running at great cost when you have got the other one anyway? Of course it will not happen, of course it is wrong, and of course it makes a joke of a competition policy. The first stage of any competition policy is competition.

We have the same deal with ANL. ANL cannot be competed with, but everything else can. It is the most stupid arrangement I have ever seen that the government is chest beating on building a competitive Australia when the three very major issues within its own absolute responsibility are sidelined and competition is openly rejected on all three. One might wonder how the next speaker will talk his way out of that.

The Department of Industry, Science and Technology recently conducted a review of the tariff classifications applying to the passenger motor vehicle sector.
