PARA.TAB: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 before the House reduces the customs duty payable on top crude oil by 31 per cent and on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene by 23 per cent. It also reduces the customs duty payable on aviation gasoline while increasing the duty on aviation kerosene.

The legislation represents the government's response to representations from industry over the significant impact of crude oil tariffs on the input costs of export based mining and mineral processing operations, the coastal shipping industry and certain manufacturing operations. Accordingly, the bill raises several important issues concerning tariff protection policies, the internationalisation of the Australian economy and trends in Australia's international trading performance. I wish to address these issues in the context of this significant legislation.

This government over the last 10 years has implemented a phased reduction in tariff walls in Australia—not the sort of cut and burn policy that the opposition took to the last federal election. Worldwide trends point towards a movement for free trade. Even when in 1996 Australia reaches an average protection level of five per cent, we will still have protection running above the OECD average. Free trade is a worldwide trend. It is reflected in the latest round of GATT. It is reflected in the arrangements now in place in the European community. It is reflected in the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement and the movement towards free trade on the American continent.

In our own region of the Asia Pacific this government has led and joined with its trading partners through APEC in moving towards freer trade—that is, to have in place by the year 2010 free trade arrangements for developed nations in the Asia Pacific and by the year 2020 for non-developed nations. It is foolish to believe that a nation in isolation can defy these trends. The mobility and spread of international capital means that old protectionist and regulation based national economic strategies no longer work. This is particularly the case for a country such as Australia where improved transport and communications have effectively ended the tyranny of economic distance and given Australia a unique opportunity in our history—that is, to use our proximity to the Asia Pacific growth region to trade our way to prosperity.

Location is now working in Australia's favour. For the first time in 200 years we now see location as an advantage, not a disadvantage, and no longer a source of fear and inward looking isolationist policies. Few nations have undergone such a rapid transformation of their trade position and their opportunities for economic growth. The key for Australia is to manage our internationalisation of the economy while preserving and enhancing the integrity of core Australian values—that is, our commitment to an independent Australian identity and social egalitarianism.

Quite frankly, over the last 20, 30, even 40 years in Australia protection has emerged as a mug's game for a small country such as ours. By doling out tariffs through the postwar period, the companies took the profits and the protection without any incentive to innovate and improve, and without any incentive to grow and employ more people. It really was a mug's game to be doling out tariffs under the regime of the federal government in the 1950s and 1960s and not offer industry any reason whatsoever to update its technology, to update its management and labour relations practices, to move into world markets and compete effectively. This left Australia by the early 1980s with an exceptionally narrow and uncompetitive industrial base.

For example, the steel industry with our resource endowments should have been one of the nation's strongest industries. Instead, it was going out the door backwards. Australian made cars were becoming less and less competitive both in price and quality. The response of the outgoing government in the early 1980s was to propose yet more protection with tariffs of up to 125 per cent. Through the 1970s and 1980s the industries which lost most jobs and discarded most workers in Australia were those that were protected most by tariffs and quotas. Profits in the same industries were well above average.

That is why I oppose and contradict totally the notion that protection has anything to do with the protection of jobs. It protects profits, not employment. It also represents a huge regressive tax on working families, draining consumption, draining aggregate demand and driving down economic growth. Protectionist policies also add to the cost of inputs for export based industries, particularly in the agricultural and mining sectors in Australia. It is very important, having discarded the failed policies of protectionism in Australia, to build an ethos of domestic and international competition. Tariffs, of course, are the most anticompetitive practice in which any government can engage.

Domestic competition directly determines the effectiveness of organisational methods and management of firms in a particular industry. A competitive environment is also likely to promote a range of resourceful and responsive supporting industries.

There are two basic ways for a small nation like Australia to maintain domestic rivalry without breaking down the size of its firms so that they are unable to compete. The first method is to keep Australia's markets open to international competition, and that is what this government is doing through its phased tariff reduction program and legislation such as this. The second measure is to follow the success of small export based nations such as Sweden and Switzerland; that is, to find a scale not available on domestic markets by taking advantage of worldwide markets and international trading opportunities.

It is obvious that a small nation like ours will not form a home base for global scale industries like car and aircraft manufacturing. Our targets must be threefold. The first is to secure Australia's future as a regional base in the Asia-Pacific region for global scale industries. I am glad to see that this is the direction we are taking. It accounts for much of the success that the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) has had in recent years. Our second target must be export based growth and import substitution in industries where Australia can develop or already has competitive advantages. Our third goal is to improve the general efficiency of the non-traded sector, recognising the great importance the efficiency of this sector holds for the cost of exports in the traded sector.

The key is competitiveness; to understand that Australia is competing not by domestic standards but by international standards, where competition is never static. It is always relative and always dynamic. It is very important to get a feel for the best means by which the parliament, the government and the Australian people can measure Australia's international competitiveness.

Traditionally economics, as a discipline, has focused on domestic indicators: GDP, unemployment, inflation and interest rates. That is still very much the focus of this parliament, the media and national debate. But domestic indicators such as those never provide the sort of relativity, the sort of comparison that is needed to accurately measure Australia's international trading competitiveness. We must shift our focus from domestic indicators to those of an international and comparative nature.

There are three methods by which a government and nation can measure its international competitiveness. The first is in the short term: to examine changes in its exchange rate and unit labour costs. These, unfortunately, do not reflect on longer-term issues such as productivity and flexibility. They may in fact reflect a depreciation, because of lower commodity prices in certain parts of the traded sector, that can make manufacturing and service exports look more competitive than they actually are once the fundamentals and the underlying efficiency of those sectors are assessed.

The second means by which a government can measure international competitiveness is through an analytical framework: that is, to provide a subjective assessment of performance. I will provide the House with two examples. Last year I received a briefing from Austrade about its analytical work on Australia's international competing and trading strengths and weaknesses. Austrade dispelled the myths about our industrial relations system and the work ethic in Australia. Austrade said that this was really not, in its experience, a barrier to our trading success.

I noticed in the December 1994 edition of Asian Business Review a list of public holidays available in the Asia-Pacific region. This will be interesting to members opposite; those who say that in Australia the work ethic is not strong enough because we have too many public holidays. This was the list of public holidays in a 12-month period in each of the nations: Hong Kong 18, South Korea 17, Taiwan 17, Japan 15, Thailand 15, Indonesia 13, New Zealand 13, Singapore 11, Vietnam 10, and then we come down to Australia with nine. Australia is well below the standard and level of public holiday availability among Asian trading nations. We were only undercut on this score by China with eight and India with seven public holidays per annum.

I notice the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) indicating that Australia does not have a strong work ethic. On the key measure of public holidays we are doing well and that dispels the myth of a poor work ethic in Australia. That is something that the Austrade officials relayed to me in their briefing in Parramatta last year.

I was also told how shipping and transport costs are critical in Australia, as is the image of our financial system. The great strength that Australia has in terms of our international competitiveness is the security and stability of our social and political systems.

I refer the House to the World Economic Forum's 1994 competitiveness report. It ranks countries in 380 performance areas using official statistics and a questionnaire survey of more than 16,000 business executives worldwide. These rankings are then combined to obtain country ranks in eight principal factors. Australia's overall ranking among 41 nations improved from 16 in 1992 to 15 in 1994. The top five were the United States of America, Singapore, Japan, Hong Kong and Germany. Australia ranked well in resource endowment and socio-political stability. However, we ranked relatively poorly in domestic capital formation, industrial production, protection levels, management performance and business transaction costs.

The third method by which a nation can measure its international competitiveness is to examine long-term trends in productivity and trade. In an internationally exposed economy, progress ultimately relies on strong productivity growth and trade performance. I refer the House to the findings of the 1991 study by Access Economics, well known to the opposition, and the Allen Consulting Group, well known to the government from the recent FitzGerald report on national savings. The report was entitled Developing Australia's national competitiveness. The report found that productivity levels in Australian agricultural and mining are high by world standards. Average manufacturing productivity was, however, 20 to 25 per cent below international best practice. The private sector labour productivity `appears to be often 10 per cent below the average international levels'. Productivity in many of our utilities is half to three-quarters of overseas levels. That is something the government will be addressing through the Hilmer reforms and package of national competition policy reforms.

It is also important to refer the House to the international performance indicators project of the Bureau of Industry Economics, which assesses the performance of Australia's infrastructure providers. The competitiveness of Australian enterprises in international markets is determined in part by the costs of inputs and services of Australian infrastructure, mainly provided by government business enterprises. These make up between 10 and 25 per cent of total costs for most industries. The report found that in each of six sectors Australia's performance was below international best practice. It provided a ratio of best Australian productivity to international best practice. For labour factors in electricity the figure was 0.3, telecommunications 0.52, rail freight 0.16, on the waterfront for coal 0.92 and on the waterfront for containers 0.84. The relative productivity on the capital factor for electricity was 0.84, telecommunications 0.78, rail freight 0.32, road freight 0.79, on the waterfront for coal it was 1.00 and on the waterfront for containers it was 0.40. The 1994 report concluded by saying that the results:

SPEECH.PARA: suggest that the degree of competition within an infrastructure industry and the rate of change of demand and technology are key determinants of infrastructure performance. The industry where Australia's performance is closest to IBP—road freight—enjoys by far the greatest degree of competition while the industry where the performance gap is largest—rail transport—suffers from the least degree of competition and the highest degree of government involvement and subsidisation.

This indicates the strategic importance of the national competition policy reforms. That is the reason why Australia, through those initiatives, can gain a five per cent increase in GDP, and why we can lower the current account deficit by almost two per cent as a proportion of national output.

PARA.TAB: In many ways Australia is at a turning point in the internationalisation and trading hopes for our economy. We spent the last 10 years opening up the economy to international trade. We must spend the next 10 years struggling, very determined, outward-looking and focused in our efforts to ensure that the economy is internationally competitive. This reflects on the suggestion of reform fatigue. Recently, in a round of interviews the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that Australians were suffering reform fatigue. He is going to be campaigning on strong values but inoffensive policies for the next election. Nothing could be more contrary to Australia's best economic interests.

We need the sorts of reforms achieved by this government through APEC—free trade in the Asia-Pacific next century—the Hilmer initiatives and the working nation program to make the labour market more efficient. Collectively, APEC-Hilmer-Working Nation represents the biggest slab of micro reform in our history, all produced over the last 12 months.
Recent reports have highlighted the economic gains to Australia of a continuous program of micro-economic reform. In May 1994 EPAC reported on the economic effects

SPEECH.PARA: of micro-economic reform based on the full implementation of an aggressive and ambitious reform scenario. The reform program, and the attainment of international best practice in all sectors, was grouped into four categories.

PARA.TAB: The first is reform in the private sector, including labour market reform, workers compensation and improved management practices. The second is phasing down tariffs—such as in this legislation—and subsidies for the manufacturing and agricultural sectors. The third is improving Australia's federal relations in the delivery of social sector services. Fourth is full competition and international efficiency in transport and communications GBEs.

EPAC estimated that while existing micro policy settings are likely to yield a long-run GDP gain of 8.2 to 8.4 per cent, a more comprehensive reform agenda could yield 13 to 15.7 per cent. These findings are confirmed by the recent work of the Industry Commission, which found that the implementation of the Hilmer agenda for national competition policies is likely to add five per cent to GDP and reduce our current account deficit by 1.9 per cent of national output.

The benefits of these huge gains are maximised by a complementary reform package. For example, competition policy provides an incentive for firms to improve efficiency, while workplace bargaining provides the organisational flexibility required to implement workplace gains. These reforms are essential if we are to achieve more sustainable rates of economic growth and overcome external constraints.

Looking at the figures—the tables, graphs and charts—for the current account deficit against the rate of unemployment since the 1970s, a clear external constraint on the economy emerges. That is, when the current account deficit approaches six per cent of GDP. In 1982, 1986 and 1990, the unemployment rate was of the order of six to eight per cent, as it is now in 1995. An externally constrained unemployment rate of that order has emerged in Australia. The major focus of micro and economic policy must be to bring down that constraint so that more sustainable rates of economic growth can be achieved and unemployment rates can be greatly lowered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is one more bill in a very long line of legislation dealing with the issue of tariffs. When I first came to Australia—over 26 years ago now—I did not know what tariffs were. I very quickly found out that Australia, an island continent down in the South Pacific, was surrounded by this huge wall called tariffs. But what are tariffs? Essentially, they are a tax—a tax on imported goods.

PARA.TAB: The theory behind tariffs is simply that if we tax imported goods we encourage local manufacture of local goods and products to meet the needs of the local marketplace. For a long time those policy settings and those parameters were effective. However, eventually tariffs became a huge cost to the community because behind the tariff wall there built up a huge set of values and understandings—or misunderstandings—in the Australian context. That included a manufacturing industry which became relatively lazy and inward looking, without particularly high quality standards or excellent service standards, and learning very little about international marketing.

Essentially, through the high tariff period, Australia was a price taker. Because we sell commodities to the rest of the world, whether off the farm or out of the ground, we became a very wealthy nation through commodities but we tried to build a manufacturing sector for high value added goods behind a wall of protection, a wall of tariffs.

In some sense, such a policy was self-defeating. I cite the motor vehicle industry as a good example. If the Holden motor company found that its prices had gone up a bit, it would go to the tariff board and say, `We must have an increase in tariffs. We want you to increase the taxes on imported motor vehicles so that we can raise the price of a Holden.' The tariff board would say `You are right. All the numbers say you are right.'

Then the union would go along to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and say, `We have a problem here. The cost of motor cars has just gone up because tariffs have gone up. Obviously, we must have an increase in our wages.' The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission would say, `You are right.' Then the company would go back to the tariff board and say, `The commission just gave our whole work force a wage increase. Our costs have gone up. We will have to have another increase in tariffs.' So the spiral would go on and on. We increased tariffs but we did nothing about improving productivity and quality or about learning about international marketing.

Gough Whitlam, an ex-Prime Minister of Australia, took a 25 per cent whack out of tariffs in the early 1970s. That sent a huge shock through Australian industry. I might also say that it wiped out one huge slab of Australian manufacturers. We used to be a proud manufacturing nation. We had a great manufacturing industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still do.

—It built the things that Australians wanted. We manufactured all kinds of things from heavy equipment to locomotives, from television sets to washing machines, driers, irons and toasters. On and on it went. We still manufacture a bit but we do not manufacture very much any more.

PARA.TAB: In 1962-63 the manufacturing industry represented 26.2 per cent of gross domestic product. In 1992-93, 30 years later, it was down to a meagre 14.7 per cent of GDP. In 1962-63, 30 years ago, manufacturing employed 31 per cent of the Australian work force. In 1992-93, and still in 1995, with 1.1 million Australians employed in manufacturing—about the same number that were employed 30 years ago—instead of that representing 31 per cent of the work force, it represents only about 16 per cent.

Our share of world trade through this time has fallen dramatically. In 1962 our output represented 1.8 per cent of world trade. In 1993 our output represented a meagre 1.2 per cent of world trade. So through the Whitlam years, and through the Hawke and Keating years, we have seen the demise of manufacturing industries in Australia—along with the fall of the tariff wall.

I am a free trader—always have been. Ever since I found out what tariffs were I decided that I was agin `em. I was absolutely against them because I thought that the imposed costs on the community were too high to bear; because they were very difficult to administer; because they set up within industry all sorts of measures which made companies look at their tariff levels rather than at what they were manufacturing; because they made companies look at how they could get around the rules and regulations rather than how they could manufacture more efficiently; because companies decided they could not possibly manufacture in Australia because of high tariffs on the imported parts needed to make technically complicated and modern equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: An Adelaide University study, released yesterday . . . provided a snapshot of Australian areas most affected by unemployment among 15 to 24-year-olds, over a six-year period.

PARA.TAB: In Victoria the worst affected areas were the Barwon Western Region, the Loddon Campaspe—

SPEECH.PARA: which I represent. It further states:
The study noted an average 21 per cent unemployment level from 1989 to 1994—the state's highest.
Academics from the Social Justice Research Foundation at the University of Adelaide carried out the research. The article continues:

. . . in a paper about the study, the foundation's Dr John Spierings said the Federal Government's Working Nation initiative did not look to directly expand the pool of jobs for young people despite a trend of declining jobs.

What an indictment. I want to raise an issue of a young man called Scott. He is 19 years of age. I will not mention his surname, as I would not want to cause him any more discomfort than he has already experienced under the government's fraudulent practices relating to its treatment of unemployed people.

PARA.TAB: Scott has been unemployed and receiving social security benefits for 18 months or more. Recently, he obtained a position on a Landcare environment action program. For working a minimum of six hours a day for five days of the week he received the princely sum of $280 per fortnight—not per week—around $4.60 per hour.

During the time he was participating in the LEAP project he heard of the possibility of a job that would lead to long-term employment if the prospective employer could receive a jobstart subsidy towards his wages. As I mentioned earlier, Scott had been a long-term unemployed person. He is desirous of working, but because he has been occupied on a LEAP project it creates problems for him. He really is in a catch-22 situation. Does he take a position under a Landcare environment program on that low wage or does he wait in the hope of receiving a job which would lead to long-term employment? This is where the manipulation starts.

I have received information from DEET about the way the system is set up. When a client goes onto a LEAP project the client is no longer classified as unemployed—that is purely for the statistics—and is therefore no longer classified as long-term unemployed. Here is a young man, 19 years of age, wanting to work, actively involved in a LEAP project. Is it any wonder that young people in our community are distressed by what is happening and any wonder that this study put out by the Adelaide University shows it up for what it is.

Due to the fact that Scott was removed from the long-term unemployed list, he would go right to the bottom of the queue of about 300,000 long-term unemployed people after he completed the LEAP scheme. What a fraud and a deceit the government is carrying out on our young people in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In short, the UQ union executive is seeking to perpetrate a virtual fraud on students of that university. The question must be asked: what will NUS do for UQ students? Apart from taking their money and funding the latest trendy issue, the answer is: very little of benefit. Effectively, UQ students will be forced to make a $100,000 plus donation to the ALP each year. Despite this, NUS has the unmitigated gall to claim in its propaganda that it stopped Labor's unconscionable changes to HECS and Austudy which were defeated in the Senate last year by the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish.

—It is rubbish. Mel Wheeler, the national education officer, claimed credit for defeating double HECS for second degrees and for ensuring that the proposal which saw students penalised for taking extra time to complete their degrees was blocked in the Senate. If the students affected should thank anyone, it should be the coalition, not the NUS, for defending their position in the Senate. It should be remembered that it did not take $100,000 from each campus or the flying of hordes of student activists around the country on junkets to achieve this.

PARA.TAB: The fact remains that despite the sanctimonious lip-service to students' rights and going through the motions of opposing the government of the day, the NUS remains a pro-ALP organisation, and an unrepresentative one at that. At UQ, for example, the fact that the union and student representatives are elected does not support the argument that the UQ union is a representative body. Only 3,000 to 4,000 students vote in these elections out of a total population of about 23,000. A group that needs only 1,500 to 2,000 votes out of a student body of 23,000 to control the union cannot be regarded as representative.

The bottom line is that if UQ joins NUS all the students will be forced to featherbed student hacks based in Melbourne. Students are forced already to pay compulsory union fees amounting to $119.50 a year before they are allowed to study. All students should ask themselves where the $100,000 odd will be found, should the union join NUS. Either the union is going to have to cut services and thus break election promises, like the Labor government, or it is going to have to raise its union fees. Whichever way is chosen, it is going to be the rank and file student who is going to lose out, either through general fee increases or cutbacks. You can bet your bottom dollar that trendy pet causes like the women's collective and the gay/lesbian/bi refuge will be shielded. It really is important that the University of Queensland union take stock of the fact that the National Union of Students does absolutely nothing for students. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no more common theme in Australian politics than the states crying poor mouth over federal funding. These are the same state governments which refused the Commonwealth's offer last year at the Darwin COAG meeting of $700 million in compensation for the introduction of national competition policies. They claimed compensation of $5 billion and called in the Industry Commission as an independent referee. The result of the report by the referee then came in. Last Friday the state Premiers agreed that no compensation was warranted; that is, they turned down cold the Commonwealth offer and missed the opportunity for additional funding of $700 million.

PARA.TAB: Many of the revenue problems of the states are discretionary and self-inflicted. In my own state of New South Wales, for instance, there are $500 million worth of payroll tax exemptions within the state budget. I want to provide to the House a further instance of state government financial mismanagement. Last week there emerged an instance of wasted federal grants in health. Let me provide the background.

In 1988 the New South Wales government agreed to and signed up for the federal government's casemix development program. For the past seven years they have cooperated with the program and received approximately $6 million in federal grants. In fact, in answer to a question on notice by the state member for Moorebank, Craig Knowles, the New South Wales health minister, Mr Phillips, on 26 October last year, provided the following answer:

SPEECH.PARA: The advantage of incorporating casemix into the budget process is to have an output related basis on which to allocate funding rather than rely on historical costs which may or may not fund appropriately.

He then went on to provide instances where casemix budgets were being introduced at Hornsby, Manly, Mona Vale and Ryde hospitals; how it was being introduced throughout the North Sydney area health service and pilots were also operating in the Illawarra health service. The minister concluded his answer by saying that the casemix models would continue.

PARA.TAB: Casemix, of course, represents a simple but effective change in the financing of hospitals. The traditional method of funding fixed annual allocations unrelated to output simply institutionalises hospital inefficiency. Hospitals would invariably increase their waiting lists as a means of attracting additional government funding. Casemix funding, which pays hospitals according to the services they perform—their output—provides a strong incentive to increase activity and cut hospital waiting lists.

In Victoria, case payments are the only way in which the public hospital system has been able to manage the 11 per cent real reduction in hospital funding by the Kennett government. Case payments in Victoria have increased productivity by 10 per cent and lowered waiting lists across the board by 15 per cent. But what happened in New South Wales last Tuesday? The health minister, Mr Phillips, announced that he would no longer proceed with the casemix reforms. That is, he threw away $6 million of federal funding for that purpose allocated over the last six years. On the one hand he turned down the opportunity for a 10 per cent efficiency gain in the New South Wales system, yet on the other hand he tried to convince the public that the Liberal Party in New South Wales would improve hospital services with the same amount of outlays. He also complained that it was the federal government that was not providing enough hospital financing.

There is absolutely no question that the New South Wales hospital system would be enhanced in all matters of efficiency and equity by the introduction of this federal based reform. In fact, output funding would advantage, in particular, outer metropolitan hospitals that are currently struggling with their throughput and patient volumes. It is regrettable, when an area such as the south-west of Sydney has 2.4 beds per thousand population while the east Sydney region has 6.7 hospital beds per thousand, the New South Wales government is throwing away a reform that would improve efficiency and allocate more hospital resources to the regions that have the highest demand in terms of patients and hospital throughput.

It is absolutely regrettable that the government in New South Wales would totally waste $6 million of federal grants, throw away the opportunity for $700 million at the Darwin COAG but still turn around and say it is the federal government's fault. That is a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of a constituent who was recently asked to participate in an Australian Bureau of Statistics unemployment survey. He received a letter informing him that his household was to complete a 52-question survey for the next eight months. The letter by the Australian Bureau of Statistics began with that immortal phrase, `I am writing to ask you for help.' Civic minded though this constituent was, he is a busy man, so he rang the ABS to decline its request to participate, only to be told that this was impossible and that Australian Bureau of Statistics officers would be calling at his home to collect the information regardless of his desire not to participate.

PARA.TAB: What did this constituent do? He rang the office of the Privacy Commissioner, only to be told by the office of the commissioner that the ABS was legally entitled to force people to participate. Even though the Privacy Commissioner had received more than 100 complaints on this subject, there was absolutely nothing that the Privacy Commissioner could or should do about it. This constituent asked to speak to the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, only to be told that Mr O'Connor never received calls from the general public. There we have it: the one person whose privacy the Privacy Commissioner seems determined to protect is his own.

We have known for many years that Big Brother is watching. Now it seems that not only is Big Brother watching, but Big Brother is asking questions; and heaven help someone who does not want to answer them. `I am from the government and I am here to help,' is one of the proverbial great lies. It really means, `I am from the government and you had better answer my questions—or else.'

While I am on my feet, and having listened to the comments of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) about the New South Wales situation, I think it is important to put on the record the fact that the New South Wales coalition government has produced multitudinous improvements in the conditions of ordinary people in my own state. Some 57 new schools have been opened and there is record spending of $5.8 billion under the Liberal coalition government. The Environment Protection Authority now has a budget of $68 million and a staff of 738. The member for Werriwa talks about transport. Those losses have been cut by half a billion dollars. More than 25 per cent of rail services ran late under the last Labor government and, now, 94 per cent of them run on time. Under Labor, one car was stolen every eight minutes and there was a break and enter every five minutes. Under the Liberal coalition government, 1,600 extra police are now on the streets and truth in sentencing means that a life sentence is just that—a life sentence.

Let me conclude by mentioning the subject of casemix, something dear to the heart of the member for Werriwa. The fact is that the Kennett government has introduced a system of casemix. That is precisely what the member for Werriwa wants the New South Wales government to adopt. If Jeff Kennett has done it there must be a lot in favour of it but it is very interesting that the member for Werriwa has lined up with Jeff Kennett. I am very happy about that but I wonder whether the member for Werriwa is really doing the right thing by his manipulators and controllers in the New South Wales Right, endorsing so fulsomely the policies of the Victorian Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett. I congratulate him for it, nonetheless.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to say a few words this evening, I would like to praise the courageous stand and leadership taken by Mr Albert Haakfort, Jim Price and Jim Edlington of Mount Isa and Jack Fraser, Eddie Lee and Ken Crisp of Cloncurry who have taken the leadership in fighting the proposals for the fly-in of workers to the new mines that are opening up in the Gulf of Carpentaria hinterland—the Mount Isa-Cloncurry area. As my colleague, the member for Maranoa (Mr Scott) would tell the House, we have lost something like 30 or 40 per cent of our population in the last 20 or 30 years. Mount Isa and Cloncurry at least have the chance of turning things around because there are some 2,000 jobs up for grabs there. The government that I was a member of in Queensland banned fly-ins to Charters Towers, and Charters Towers picked up 1,200 jobs. We banned fly-ins to Emerald and we saw that queen city of the inland grow from 6,000 people—the honourable member for Maranoa is nodding his head—to nearly 12,000 people.

It was not a very successful experiment in the case of the black people and I am damned sure it is not going to be a very successful experiment with the population of the gulf country today.

I say to the shareholders and the boards of the companies whose managements are proposing this to their shareholders that they are being conned. I rang the most clever, astute and able mining manager in Australia and asked him about this issue. I said, `What do you think about running a mine near Burketown from Brisbane—and I am referring to Century Zinc?' He said, `If a person walked through my door and proposed that to me, he would not walk out the door without a signed statement of resignation on my table.' He also said, `To suggest for one moment that even middle management, such as the foremen and leading hands, could be based in Brisbane is as stupid as suggesting the work force should be based in Brisbane when the mine is near Burketown.' You can almost watch the waves roll in at Century Zinc.

I would also note that these are the people who are portraying the interests of their shareholders and the interests of the Australian nation badly because these mines will simply not function or perform in any way that is acceptable. We have never had a happy day at Mount Isa since the management moved away from the city and into the big southern capital of Brisbane.

On behalf of the leadership of these towns, I give the warning that things are going to grow increasingly unpleasant if we do not have a change of attitude. We have no movement from the state government—the architect of destruction in inland Queensland. We most certainly have had a situation precipitated by the ridiculous fringe benefits tax that levies an imposition upon people who want to provide services to their own employees and enable their employees to go home and have a family life.

At the moment, the proposal that is being put forward will remove fathers who are working on the mine fields in the gulf country of Queensland from the family unit. We are talking about 6,000 or 7,000 workers who will ultimately be involved throughout this region. It will be a very sad day for Australia. It was banned in Western Australia and the decision was only reversed when certain corrupt payments were made to the Western Australian government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the brief time available to me, I want to throw the spotlight once again on the ridiculous situation the government has created in relation to superannuation funds, particularly occupational funds. We heard recently that Australia taxes voluntary or discretionary savings at the highest level in the OECD. It is an incredible situation.

PARA.TAB: It has been noted before and deserves revisitation that the level of fees charged by many institutions to set up and manage occupational funds is excessive, often leading to the complete eradication of any so-called benefits accrued during the time of membership. For example, let us take the cases of just two of my constituents—Mr Greg Boyd and Mr Trevor Freeman.

Let me take Mr Boyd's case first because his situation demonstrates very well the differences in the way funds siphon off funds of these kind. Mr Boyd received an annual membership statement from the Norwich Union Superannuation Trust, into which his employer, a courier company, had been contributing the compulsory super requirement. Over the 1993-94 financial year, this amounted to $694, all being superannuation guarantee contribution payments. From this, Norwich deducted $60 in membership fees; a $138.80 contribution fee; $2.89 in asset fees; $52 in death and disability insurance, which is fair enough; and another $66.05 in contributions tax. This left Mr Boyd with a grand total of $368.21, almost exactly half of the contributions paid into his account by his employer.

Who is the SGC trying to guarantee a future for? Not Mr Boyd and others like him. More likely this is a scheme designed to guarantee the continuing existence of superannuation funds that charge fees such as this. In contrast, Mr Boyd left that employer and worked for another company which also paid occupational super through the SGC scheme. This policy was held with Legal and General's SuperEasy. Between May and September 1994, Mr Boyd's company contributions totalled $140.72. After deduction of insurance, contribution fees and tax, Mr Boyd received $93.89, a far better outcome than his previous fund.

While no-one can argue that fees of varying types are part and parcel of insurance and superannuation, the level and diversity of these are staggering. On the one hand, some funds seem to charge reasonable and sensible fees, while other companies leave employees with greatly reduced funds. If superannuation companies do not want to service the small operator why is this government forcing them to—thus allowing the more unscrupulous to profit from small investors?

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Telecom devolved centralised purchasing decisions to departmental management with the result that purchases have not been made through Department of Administrative Services (DAS) contracts; if so, (a) when did this occur, (b) what purchasing requirements were affected, (c) has the devolution resulted in (i) no pricing guidelines, (ii) the scrapping of a central equipment and assets register and (iii) loss of purchasing skills and bulk buying pressures and (d) has the purchase or use of photocopying and associated equipment left the purchasing system open to exploitation.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to allegations that (a) some companies, in providing photocopying and other equipment to Telecom, have inflated the purchase price above that applying under DAS contracts and extended the period for rental payments from 3 to 5 or more years resulting in 2 to 3 times the yield on capital, (b) part of the additional yield was offered back to the purchasers as an incentive to buy equipment at no real cost with the companies retaining the balance and (c) a sum of $15-16 million is involved; if so, will he investigate the matter and establish which companies were involved and what advantage each gained.

(3) Does he approve the departments or agencies for which he has portfolio responsibility purchasing outside the contracts negotiated by Purchasing Australia; if so, what controls has he implemented to ensure best value for money.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Government Business Enterprises, including Telstra, are not required to purchase against DAS arrangements. I am advised by Telstra that the Company requires that any product sourcing arrangements entered into must represent best value for money. All Telstra product sourcing recommendations are required to be extensively evaluated. As part of this evaluation, the Corporate Sourcing Unit, which is responsible for arranging product sourcing agreements, compares the offer against any Purchasing Australia arrangements which may exist and often uses these as a benchmark.

Telstra has advised that they have devolved some responsibility for purchasing decisions to Business Units under appropriate delegations. In making purchase decisions Business Units refer to product sourcing arrangements entered into by the Corporate Sourcing Unit. I am further advised by Telstra that:
(a) Devolution occurred on a progressive basis from 1986 to 1988.
(b) Delegation was devolved for purchase of a range of commercially available non-stocked products and services.
(c)(i) No. Pricing guidelines apply.

(c)(ii) No, Telstra maintains a central accounting asset register to meet both its accounting and tax requirements. While there are no accounting or taxation requirements to maintain a register of leased assets, Telstra includes these assets in a fixed asset register. Telstra's policy is that all commercially attractive non-communication assets whether owned or leased are registered so as to enable management to exercise physical control over such assets.
(c)(iii) Telstra has established national sourcing contracts and agreements for a range of products and services to maximise its buying power and to ensure availability.

(d) No problems were encountered with the outright purchase of equipment. Leasing arrangements for office equipment did result in some exploitation, but processes are now in place to ensure that there is no recurrence.
(2) Telstra has further advised that:

(a) The price of some office equipment was inflated to offset the value of incentive products such as facsimile machines. Telstra has advised that the effect in the yield on capital was less than indicated by the honourable member. (See also response to (2) (c)).

(b) Incentive products were included in some purchasing of office equipment. After preliminary inquiries by Telstra, information relating to leasing arrangements has been forwarded to the Victorian Police to see if there were any criminal actions that could be pursued in relation to this matter. Following this, criminal charges were laid against a former employee and other matters are still subject to investigation.

(c) Telstra has also held discussions with five leading photocopier companies. These discussions led to many leasing arrangements being adjusted in Telstra's favour or refunds being provided which offset any premiums charged for incentives. The value of these favourable adjustments was approximately $1.3 million in Telstra's favour. This represented an 8 per cent reduction in leasing exposure for photocopiers and facsimile machines, which now stands at approximately $15 million.

(3) The Government agreed as part of the reforms of Government Business Enterprises that Telstra not be bound by DAS purchasing arrangements. Telstra has advised that it recently established its own photocopier and facsimile contractual arrangements to ensure that its purchasing practices are capable of providing best value for money. At the time of entering into these arrangements, the equipment available on Purchasing Australia (DAS) contracts was taken into consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that residents of Yanchep and Two Rocks, WA, have been waiting since 1992 to be included in a trial of Telecom's ReachOut program.
(2) Did Telecom make a commitment to the residents of Yanchep and Two Rocks to provide untimed local calls to the area; if so, when will Telecom fulfil its commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom advise me that Telecom staff discussed the ReachOut 75 trials to take place in Rockingham, WA at a public forum attended by many Yanchep and Two Rocks residents in June 1993, however, they did not indicate that Yanchep and Two Rocks would be included in a trial of ReachOut 75.
(2) Yanchep and Two Rocks residents have had untimed local calls for many years.
Telecom advise me that it has made no commitment to Yanchep and Two Rocks residents to provide untimed calls to Perth under ReachOut 75.

I am advised that AUSTEL disallowed ReachOut 75 on the grounds that it was anti-competitive, that it constituted predatory pricing, and that it was discriminatory because it was only to have been offered to a limited range of subscribers. I understand that before the tariff was disallowed, extensive discussions between AUSTEL and Telecom took place.

The Government's policy is that AUSTEL must disallow anti-competitive tariffs of a dominant carrier. AUSTEL, as the independent regulator, also has discretion to determine whether discriminatory tariffs are cost-related, in the community interest or trials (and hence exempt from the anti-discrimination provisions). Telecom is aware of its requirement to comply with this regulatory framework.
AUSTEL has recently authorised Telecom to conduct a trial of ReachOut 100. The six month trial began at Geelong in Victoria from 12 December 1994, and at Southport in Queensland from 23 January 1995.

Under ReachOut 100 Telecom customers will be able to make calls up to a radius of 100 kms of their exchange for a flat rate of $1.00 for 15 minutes. Subsequent usage is charged at the standard rate for the type of call. Local calls are not included and will remain at 25 cents.

Whether ReachOut 100 is fully implemented after the completion of the trial will be a commercial decision from Telecom and will depend upon AUSTEL's views upon whether the tariff conforms with discrimination and anti-competitive requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The frequency and nature of reports due under the Covenant are set by the UN's Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC), under whose aegis the Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights monitors States parties compliance with the obligations of the Covenant.

In 1976, shortly after the Covenant came into force, ECOSOC instituted a three phase reporting cycle according to which States parties were required to make initial reports, at three-yearly intervals, on different clusters of the substantive

ANSWER.PARA: rights recognised in articles 6 to 15 of the Covenant (6-9, 10-12 and 13-15). This system meant that a complete initial reporting cycle took nine years. After completing the initial reporting cycle, States parties submitted subsequent, or periodic, reports (on the same three clusters of rights) every two years, which constituted a six year cycle.

PARA.TAB: A new reporting cycle was introduced in 1988 in order to streamline the reporting process. Beginning in 1992, States parties are now required to submit an initial comprehensive report, dealing with the entire Covenant, within two years of the Covenant's entry into force for the State concerned. Every five years thereafter, a single comprehensive periodic report is required.
The Committee on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights can request a State party to submit additional information to supplement that already provided in a report by the State party concerned.

(2) Australia's most recent report, the second periodic report on articles 13-15 of the Covenant, was produced in January 1992. An Australian delegation, led by the Hon Barry Jones MP, attended the Committee's meetings on 24 and 25 May to answer questions arising from the Committee's consideration of the report.

(3) It was not practice to table reports in Parliament at the time that the second periodic report was prepared. The 1992 Review of Australia's Efforts to Promote and Protect Human Rights by the Human Rights Sub-Committee of the Parliament's Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade (JCFADT) recommended changes to procedures for preparing reports under international covenants. The procedures for preparing reports were subsequently changed so that Australian reports are presented to the JCFADT as part of the annual report when they occur in that year, and the reports are tabled in Parliament to facilitate public scrutiny of both the reports and the UN response to them.

(4) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is the central co-ordinating department responsible for producing reports under the Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights. The substantive responses under each of the articles are produced by Commonwealth departments and agencies with primary responsibility for policy and services related to the article in question.
